Valehunters
‚ä∞‚ïê Aldis ‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ä± / ‚ú®aldis / Far Traveler
Daarka 3/12/2023 9:39 PM
@Dakota
2
Daarka 3/12/2023 9:57 PM
Spring was on its way, but wasn't quite settled into Fielbarry yet. A layer of frost still tended to cover everything, though there was rarely deep snowfall anymore. And during the daytime, when the sun was shining uninhibited, it was very nearly a pleasant temperature outside. To everyone except Skena, for whom it was still decidedly cold. Bundled up as if it were still the dead of winter, she had taken a rare trudge out to the beehives to see how they were handling the season. She didn't go so far as to open the hives, wanting to preserve whatever insulated heat they had managed to stir up as they hunkered down. She noted the few bees that had left the hives solely to relieve themselves, but had succumbed to the cold before making their way back into safety, and now lay dead in the snow just outside the entrance to their homes. While it was inevitable and expected, she couldn't help but find it a little sad, despite herself. Still, not too many had perished, certainly not a quantity that would be cause for concern or indicate a severe toll on the overall population. She left the little deceased bees where they lay--she already had too many dead bees at home than she knew what to do with--and idly shuffled around to look things over in a mostly hands-off way, checking for signs of problems that warranted intervention. And pleased when she found none. "Not much longer to spring, now," she murmured softly, as if the hives were actively giving her their undivided attention. The lid of one got a single, gentle pat, and she took a deep breath, sighing it out as she turned to head back home. As her awareness opened up to a larger periphery again, a small movement caught her eye. She paused, glancing through the trees, expecting to glimpse a deer or the like. But there was no such shape there, and after a pause, she turned to resume her trek back home. After all, it was a forest; even her keen perceptions weren't going to catch all the little critters that had evolved specifically to navigate the environment subtly. Her shoes made quiet little crunches in the frost, but... it was more than that. Something about the sounds of the woods around her were just a little bit off in a way she couldn't put her finger directly on. And the more she focused on it, trying to single out what was making her increasingly uncomfortable, the more that discomfort felt... familiar, in an odd way. Guided. Like the soundless voice of a trusted guardian lending advice. And she knew better than to disregard that. She continued to walk home, though she gradually began to detour from the path so she would ultimately not arrive at the home at all. As she walked, ensuring her body language remained unchanged, she reached out to the familiar presence of Kaleva's mind in the ether. 'Might be nothing... but I feel like I'm being followed. Between the hives and home.' As she spoke the message, she paused, before rummaging in a pocket and pulling out three knucklebones. Still while walking, she rolled them in her hand once, and then let them drop into the opposite palm, looking over them with as empty an expression as she could manage. '... It's not nothing,' she tacked on to the remainder of her spell.
Dakota 3/12/2023 10:34 PM
Kaleva had been hanging some fish onto the drying racks when Skena's message came through, and he froze for a second, then turned and bolted into the cabin, the playing dogs all stopping in their play to follow him. 'I'm coming. Just hang on. Atreyu and I will find you.' He threw on his armor and grabbed his swords, not even bothering with Atreyu's tack as he climbed up onto the hound's back. "Skena's being followed. There might be danger. She went to check on the bees." Atreyu perked his ears and let out a worried whine, and Kaleva turned to look at the huskies. "Song, Finch, stay home." When both huskies went inside, he and the Cautican hound took off at a run, all senses on alert.
Daarka 3/12/2023 10:40 PM
It wouldn't be hard to find her, though she had deviated from the shortest path between the hives and home--not wanting to lead a stranger back to their residence. She exhaled a soft breath of relief as she heard the thudding of large paws, and glanced up from her rather tense stroll to give Kaleva and Atreyu a small, slightly tempered smile. But if something was following her, it at least had not seemingly attacked or otherwise approached in the time it took Kaleva to arrive. "Hey, buddy," she greeted softly, reaching to give Atreyu's nose a reassuring rub, trying to keep her posture relaxed out of some reflexive assumption that having some semblance of the element of surprise would make whatever was to come easier, and so not wanting to betray that she suspected anything. But simultaneously, she reached out to Kaleva's mind again. 'Don't know who or what. Thought I saw something, or heard something. Rolled bones for if it warranted concern. They said yes.'
Dakota 3/12/2023 10:55 PM
'Good to know. We'll go for a run, head to Fielbarry. Atreyu will be a tight fit in Finder's Keepers but I think we can squeeze him through the door.' Atreyu wagged his tail and snuffled Skena, checking her over for injuries while Kaleva reached a hand down for her to help her up onto the hound's back. Out loud, he said, "The Guild reached out and wanted to speak with us. Not sure what's going on, but it sounded important."
Daarka 3/12/2023 10:59 PM
Skena reached up to take his hand, helping pull herself up onto Atreyu's back behind him with some effort (she wasn't exactly known for her upper body strength). As she settled behind him and fit her arms around his waist, she kept her head still while sharply lifting her gaze to rake through the trees that had been at her back as she walked. As Atreyu had just turned to change direction back towards town, there was a small, quiet inhale from Skena, and she hissed under her breath towards Kaleva's ear, "I see them," followed a moment later by an even quieter, "I'm not crazy."
Dakota 3/13/2023 7:12 AM
His pointed ear twitched at her whisper, his tail briefly coiling around one of her calves and giving it a reassuring squeeze. "I believe you," he murmured lowly, searching their surroundings with his other senses while Atreyu loped through the forest.
Daarka 3/13/2023 1:14 PM
Skena kept an eye out as well, but fell silent, quietly appreciating the comfort of having her family now beside her. As they ran, Kaleva would notice nothing out of the ordinary; no sounds or scents that caught his attention. If something had been there, they had seemingly left it behind them. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Skena murmured after a while. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean to make you stress out.‚Äù
Dakota 3/13/2023 1:29 PM
Kaleva glanced back over his shoulder at her. "Don't apologize, I'd rather make the run out here and not have anything happen than the alternative. I couldn't sense anything, but that doesn't mean there was nothing there. You're safe. That's what matters." As Fielbarry came into view in the distance, he slowed Atreyu to a trot, fingers lightly gripping the loose skin of his nape for lack of a mane or reins. "You want to pick up something while we're in town? I've had a hankering for churros."
Daarka 3/13/2023 1:31 PM
Skena chuckled softly, trying to sigh off the last of the tension. ‚ÄúChurros sounds great. I don‚Äôt need one of the full sized ones, though.‚Äù
Dakota 3/13/2023 1:55 PM
"We can split an order. I'll eat whatever you don't." A brief pit stop for churros and they headed to Finders Keepers, squeezing Atreyu in past all the junk and up the stairs. It was a good thing Atreyu was so skinny and intelligent, mindfully picking his way through and careful not to knock anything over. Once they were safe home, Kaleva released the dogs back outside and sat at the table with Skena, dipping his churro in the sugary glaze and munching on it. "You said back there you could see them... What did they look like?"
Daarka 3/13/2023 2:18 PM
Skena settled down opposite him, having broken off about three inches of the churro for herself. She frowned a little in thought. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt get a great look. But it kind of looked like a man? Maybe? Honestly it‚Ä¶ could have been a woman, I guess. My first impression was just male‚Ä¶ Maybe a human or elf or‚Ä¶ something that passes fairly well for one. Hard to really tell height‚Ä¶ they didn‚Äôt seem super small like me, or hugely tall, but they were pretty far away. And half behind a tree. Not hugely bulky, also not notably slender. Just... Just a person. I only saw one figure‚Ä¶ I never saw evidence of there being more than one, but‚Ä¶ I really can‚Äôt say.‚Äù A pause, before she heaved a sigh. "I'm sorry--that's the worst description ever. I mean--I didn't see horns. I didn't see a snout. I didn't see anything that would have been a prominent feature like that, it just... looked like a person. I don't know, maybe it was Yiska." She shrugged a little meekly, taking a nibble of her minichurro. "I had been checking the hives, and thought I glimpsed something in the corner of my eye. Just... movement. I looked for it, but couldn't pick out what had caused that movement, so I figured it was some animal. But when I started walking back, it was like... I... I didn't definitely hear something following me, but... it was like someone was taking care to only take a step at the same time I did, so their footsteps were disguised in the sound of mine. And it created just... this... uncanny valley feeling. And I got a strange creeping sensation in my skull..." (edited)
Dakota 3/13/2023 4:11 PM
Kaleva frowned in thought while he munched on his snack, his tail flipping about in restless thought. "I doubt it was Yiska. He'd have no reason to hide from you, or stalk you. He's pretty straightforward about engaging with us. If it was someone working for Oberon..." He shook his head slightly. "I'll go talk with Yiska, see if he's seen or heard anything out of the ordinary, and ask if he'd let us know if he and his pack encounter anything unusual. Do you want me to go with you next time you check on the bees?"
Daarka 3/13/2023 4:13 PM
Skena sighed again. "I mean... I won't have to check them again for another couple weeks. They're still hunkered down for the winter, so there's not much to check." She paused to take another small bite of her churro, thinking while she chewed. "... Want me to send Yiska a message? Have him head over if he's available and touch base?"
Dakota 3/13/2023 4:29 PM
"Sure, might as well." He chomped down the last of his churro and licked his fingers clean, pausing mid-lick to crinkle up his nose and make an icky face, smacking his lips. "Oh, I should not have done that. I was handling fish before I rode out to you." Kaleva pushed himself up from his chair to go wash his hands.
Daarka 3/13/2023 4:31 PM
Skena blinked, then snorted at his revelation. He was remarkably calm about the situation--or perhaps she was just ready to plunge into a full scale anxiety attack in comparison. Either way, it was helping settle her nerves. 'Are you available to come by our home? We wanted to ask if you've noticed something. Can trade some food for the trouble.'
Dakota 3/14/2023 9:40 PM
There was a bit of a pause before she received a reply, and when he did, it was a sort of wordless rumble that seemed to convey an affirmative. Hopefully. It was true, Kaleva did seem to be calm about the situation, but he was calm because Skena was on the verge of an anxiety attack, knowing all too well that they'd both feed off each other and fret themselves to pieces jumping at ghosts if he didn't keep control of himself. So he went about things as though they were safe, or that if there was trouble, it wasn't anything they couldn't handle. He kept his armor and weapons on while they waited for Yiska, the only indication that he wasn't about to relax and dismiss what had happened. The huskies kicked up a din to announce Yiska's arrival, the shifter dressed in his winter furs - clothing they had learned early in the winter he'd had made of the skins of fallen pack members, his family. To some, the idea might seem horrific. To Yiska, it was simple. The pack supported and looked out for each other in life. In death they continued to do so by helping protect him from the elements. Kaleva had asked if he'd wanted any of the skins of the kills he made to reinforce the wolf-skin clothing, and Yiska had simply looked at him in confusion and stated that he was not a rabbit, so why would he wear their furs and smell like prey? Three of Yiska's family were with him - Two pups from the previous spring's litter, and their aunt. They all crowded around sniffing each other, re-familiarizing themselves, and then the husky and wolf pups started to play, frolicking around the yard while their aunt looked on, staying by Yiska's side as Kaleva went to the door. "Hi, thanks for coming."
Daarka 3/14/2023 10:11 PM
Skena followed Kaleva out to greet the shifter, offering him a small smile. She had found him much easier to interact with when she realized his emoting situation was very similar to Mahva's, and then any strangeness quickly melted away. "Yes, we appreciate it. I had, um. I had been checking my bee hives, and got the feeling I was being followed. Kaleva came to pick me up, but I think I glimpsed someone in the woods before we left the area. You haven't happened to notice anything, have you...? Any signs of strangers wandering through?" A beat. "Also that offer for food still stands. Just let me know if you'd like something--just in trade for you taking the time to come out here."
Dakota 3/14/2023 10:32 PM
One of Yiska's pointed ears swiveled to the side, and he sniffed briefly, letting out a small grunt. "Yes. Passed through that area on the way here, picked up the scent of a stranger with the smell of unfamiliar wolf about them." The female wolf with Yiska was sniffing at Kaleva's tail, head and tail cautiously low. The tiefling flicked it unconsciously in response to Yiska's words, and then let out a yelp when teeth abruptly nipped and tugged at it. The yelp startled the wolf as much as him, and she jolted away and skittered halfway across the yard. Kaleva let out a little snort, then breathed deep and looked back to Yiska. "Unfamiliar wolf - like a werewolf, like us?" "No. Not werewolf." Yiska's lips thinned faintly as he searched for the right words. "Had been around a wolf. Close enough to gain scent."
Daarka 3/14/2023 10:35 PM
Skena's brows furrowed softly in thought, barely distracted by the wolf-biting-tail shenanigans. "... That... doesn't really ring a bell for me. Something with a relevance towards wolves doesn't... overtly sound like anything from Cautica...?" She wondered, glancing at Kaleva to see if he had a better clue.
Dakota 3/14/2023 10:44 PM
"It doesn't," Kaleva agreed, folding his arms and frowning. "...So maybe it has nothing to do with that. But now I'm worried that it has something to do with me - someone going after you to get to me, or something along those lines." He blinked. "...I don't know if that sounds... selfish or narcissistic, it's just... If either of us was going to attract attention from someone affiliating with wolves... And there was the whole thing with Fenrir's cult recently." Yiska gave them a bit of a blank stare, following very little of what they were talking about.
Daarka 3/14/2023 10:50 PM
Skena shook her head. "It doesn't sound narcissistic, I know what you mean." Glancing at Yiska, she gave him a slightly apologetic smile as she saw the look on his face. "We've... had some bad experiences. And it's led to... potentially a handful of people we'd prefer to avoid. I'm starting to think maybe you have the right of it, and we should just go live in the woods and cut ourselves off from society," she added wryly. "Um. Thank you for sharing what you can, Yiska. I feel a little rude not inviting you inside, since that's so normal for us to do, but I get the feeling you wouldn't want to be inside anyways. Would you like anything in return for your time in coming out here? Food, drink, supplies...?"
Dakota 3/16/2023 8:46 PM
Skena was correct in her assessment. Yiska had zero desire to go inside their home, and as she mentioned it, his gaze shifted to the doorway of their cabin in a sort of wary glance. At her question, he paused, then sniffed at the air. "...I smell fish." "We do have plenty of that," Kaleva said with a small smile. "Let me get you a string of them. How many are in your pack now?" "Twelve," the shifter confirmed in a low murmur, shifting his gaze to where the wolves and huskies were now engaged in a spirited tug of war with scraps of a deer hide that Kaleva had let them go nuts over. His pale gray eyes refocused on Skena after a moment. "If I sense them again, I will howl a warning. Kaleva will be able to distinguish its meaning from other howls if you are not able to."
Daarka 3/16/2023 8:53 PM
"I'm certainly not able to, no--but thank you. It's enough for me that Kaleva will understand," Skena replied gently, gratefully. "Just... if you do sense them again, you may also want to... avoid them," she continued slowly. "... Until Kaleva and I understand who's out there, who might... be following me... There's... There's just too many people I worry would want to do us harm in some way or another. The last thing I want is for you or your pack to get tangled up in that, and... since we have no idea what this danger might be, I'm inclined to err on the side of just... full and total caution."
Dakota 3/16/2023 8:59 PM
"If they bring strange wolves into my territory, we will confront them," Yiska replied. "We will not tolerate their presence. We will not be driven out without a fight." Kaleva returned from the fish house, two dozen sizeable fish strung through the gills and carried over his back, which he passed off to Yiska. The other werewolf gave a small grunt of acknowledgement and held it at his side, though when the female crept closer, he growled at her in warning, and she backed off with an appeasing grin and tail wags.
Daarka 3/16/2023 9:03 PM
Skena exhaled softly, nodding. "... Then I won't suggest you do otherwise. But if it comes to that conflict, and you are losing that fight, I hope you will call to us and allow us to come to your aid. Hopefully none of this comes to pass, though."
Dakota 3/16/2023 9:13 PM
"...I will consider it. You are not part of the pack, but you are part of this territory. You have a right to help defend it." He turned then and began to leave, making a deep whuff toward the other wolves, who reluctantly stopped their game and went to follow. He paused before he left and glanced back at them over his shoulder. "Good luck." Kaleva lifted a hand to wave them off, and called the huskies back before they could follow. He sighed and rubbed the back of his neck with a grimace. "Well, at least that erases any sort of doubt. I'm glad he picked up on it, because I couldn't smell a thing."
Daarka 3/16/2023 9:17 PM
"You as well," Skena murmured after the shifter. Once he had gone, she looked back to Kaleva with a slight wince. "... I wish I had any better idea of what was going on, though. Or... what we should even do about it. It feels like... there's not much we can do, other than to just... wait for something else to happen."
Dakota 3/16/2023 9:35 PM
"Hurry up and wait," Kaleva agreed. He sighed deeply and gave her a gentle nudge. "I'm going to try to relax and do some painting. Sit with me a bit?"
Daarka 3/16/2023 9:39 PM
"Of course," she replied easily, turning to follow him inside. As she went, she detoured briefly to head towards Atreyu. "Hey, buddy. We're a little worried there might be someone out in the woods who might be trying to find me, but we're not sure. If you think you hear or smell someone outside, give us a good boof, okay?"
Dakota 3/16/2023 9:40 PM
"Boof!" Atreyu replied with a toss of his head and a wag of his tail. He leaned in to give her a hefty nuzzling that was almost enough to knock her off her feet, and then went and marched off with a prancing gait to go patrol the area. No one was gonna find his mommy on his watch.
Daarka 3/16/2023 9:49 PM
Skena smiled softly, endeared by the puppy, before turning to join Kaleva. The night would pass uneventfully, with Skena and Kaleva finding a measure of peace amidst their self care. The next day... was much of the same. They both remained a bit on edge, but tentatively allowing themselves to go through their day as normal--though Skena made it a point to stay within earshot of Kaleva at all times. That night, too, came and went without incident, and it was beginning to look like maybe it had been nothing after all. It was the third night, if he was still tasking himself with patrol, when Atreyu's dutiful senses would pick up a presence from outside the cabin.
Dakota 3/16/2023 9:55 PM
Atreyu's floppy ears perked up, hackles raising as he lifted his head. He let out a single, sharp bark - a noise that immediately startled Kaleva awake, because the hound, for all his boofs and grumbles and whines and other various noises, rarely ever actually barked. Kaleva threw back the covers and climbed out of bed immediately, only clad in pajama pants, heading for where his scimitars were kept and grabbing them up as he crept quietly to peek out the window.
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:04 PM
Skena also jolted awake, blinking rapidly, and then scrambling after Kaleva with her heart rising into her throat. She didn't join him in creeping towards the window, not wanting to give away his position with her own, far worse abilities with stealth. Instead, she moved towards Atreyu, placing a hand on the back of his neck and quietly murmuring, "Good boy, thank you, Tre." As she pet him, an eye warily on the windows, a faint golden glow began to blossom from her fingertips, subtle, but present. Several long seconds ticked by in silence. Almost a full minute had elapsed, before... Knock... knock... Skena's slightly widened eyes jerked towards Kaleva, wordlessly exchanging a look for a moment. And then, uncertainly, making a vague gesture as if to ask who should answer the door.
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:08 PM
Finch and Song were unusually silent as they followed their family. While they had no issues kicking up a fuss for visitors, they seemed to know immediately that something was wrong, and stayed close to Skena's sides. At the knock, Kaleva's eyes darted to Skena, every fiber of hair running down his neck and back standing on end. But he wasn't about to put Skena on the front lines, so he went to the door and growled through it, "What do you want."
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:11 PM
Skena inched forward to be closer to Kaleva's back as he moved forward, not wanting him to move too far out of reach just as much as he didn't want her in the front line. Her unblinking gaze stayed on the door as she waited with held breath, magic poised and held on her fingertips. There was only silence for a few long moments. A slightly awkward stretch of time, before... a voice--male, tired... a little meek--finally did respond. "... To talk."
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:15 PM
Kaleva narrowed his eyes, and he let a growl carry through his voice as he replied, his shoulder pressed to the wood as if ready to bar a potential attempted break-in, "It's two in the morning. We don't know who you are. We don't know why you've been stalking us. Tell us why we would want to talk to you."
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:17 PM
Another awkward pause, though slightly shorter this time. "... I'm... I'm sorry. I didn't... mean to scare either of you..." Another pause. "... Didn't realize... how late it's gotten. I can... I can come back later."
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:20 PM
The tiefling glanced to Skena for her take on things, on whether or not this person was genuinely being this way or if it was a lure. She could read people better than he could. "Who even are you?"
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:26 PM
Skena was listening with rapt attention, and as Kaleva glanced at her, she swallowed to clear her throat, and faintly whispered, "... If it's just him... we should have the upper hand... and I have ways of controlling things..." Another long pause, as the unknown presence seemed stumped by an arguably predictable question. "... You don't know me," he finally replied, slowly, sounding lost. "... I... have more than one name." Another pause. "I think... the one that feels... most relevant is... Ludin."
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:28 PM
"Are you alone, or do you have other people with you?" Kaleva's voice was low and curt, that undercurrent of a growl still flavoring his tone. "I will not hesitate to kill you if you make the slightest attempt to bring harm to me or mine."
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:30 PM
"I'm alone." That answer seemed to come easier. "I... I have a sword... a sword and a dagger. I can... leave them out here if... if that matters."
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:37 PM
"Set them down in front of the window and return to the door," Kaleva said flatly. "Keep your hands in front of you, fingers interlaced and palms together. Do you have any magical items on you?"
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:42 PM
Another pause. "... My. My sword is enchanted. I... I'd like it back when I leave. That's all, though... That's all." Silence. And then faint sounds of shuffling as footsteps carried the stranger around to the nearest window. A few more shuffling sounds as a belt was unstrapped, a few small weighted objects dropping onto the small layer of snow and frost on the ground. Then quiet shuffles of footsteps returning to the door. Skena's gaze alternated between the window, the door, and Kaleva, and as it seemed their visitor had finished following instructions, she gave a tiny nod to Kaleva to confirm she was braced to act at the first sign of trouble.
Dakota 3/16/2023 10:45 PM
"I'm not interested in stealing from you," Kaleva said curtly. Once he'd complied with the demands, he unlocked and opened the door to take a look at this 'Ludin', eyes narrowed and hackles bristled, his tail flicking in tight lashes.
Daarka 3/16/2023 10:56 PM
Skena swiftly positioned herself so she could have eyes on the stranger as well, though kept Kaleva between them in the opening of the doorway. 'Ludin' was an odd figure. A man, maybe half a head taller than Kaleva himself, but with the slightest hunch in his posture, as if his shoulders were always a fraction curled in, creating a very nearly timid demeanor. He had a silvery complexion, and would have been clean-shaven if not for a bit of stubble that had yet to be seen to. His hair was dark, falling in wind-tousled locks that cut off roughly between his jaw and his shoulders, and was streaked in white. His ears were elfin, but simple, and he was dressed in furs and leathers that looked well suited for traveling in the winter, but were just slightly a bit excessive for this far south. But his most prominent features were twofold: his eyes were pupilless spheres of an almost electric blue--and above either brow, his slightly-messy hair half concealed what looked to be perfectly symmetrical, aged burn scars in relatively neat oval shapes, with an outer and inner ring within them that had a slight variance in coloration. Though it was not explicitly clear what with his lack of pupils, Ludin seemed to look exclusively at Kaleva as the door opened, his hands meekly clasped together in front of him. But, though his lips parted a little and brows furrowed ever so slightly, he didn't seem to immediately find his words.
10:57 PM
SPOILER
Dakota 3/16/2023 11:10 PM
Kaleva took barely a moment to take in his appearance, flicking his gaze past him to silently search behind him into the surrounding forest. He then looked back to Ludin, scimitars still in hand, standing in the doorway and clearly not about to invite him in. "You were the one following Skena a few days ago?" he prompted, a slight motion of his head indicating to the aasimar behind him.
Daarka 3/16/2023 11:15 PM
Skena also took the opportunity to look into the surrounding woods--but neither she nor Kaleva would see signs of anyone else. Ludin winced slightly. "... I... I didn't know she was with you. And I didn't mean any harm, I just... just stumbled across someone in the middle of the forest. Behaving kind of odd." He gave a small, tense inhale. "... I don't... mean anything by that. Just... the... the talking to boxes. Didn't understand it. I had been... originally coming the same direction she ended up leaving in. Tried to just... hang back and... stay unnoticed. Habit, I guess. Wasn't... following her. Wasn't gonna do anything to her." A beat. "... Got the feeling she was uncomfortable. When... When you showed up, I realized she was with you. I... didn't... I. I don't know, I... feel like I've already blundered all of this."
Dakota 3/16/2023 11:19 PM
He felt the odd need to defend Skena's eccentricities. "They were her beehives," he said shortly, though he felt some of his hostility easing back when the man explained his and Skena's encounter to be accidental. "Why don't you start with what you want from me, then."
Daarka 3/16/2023 11:25 PM
Ludin's jaw clenched and unclenched a few times, and it wasn't solely Skena who would be able to pick up on the insecurity coming off of the man in waves. "... To... To speak with you. To know you. If--If you'd allow it. I... would have come sooner, but I... I had no idea what became of you. No idea where to find you." A beat, before he rather awkwardly added, "If--If you have no interest in that, I won't... force anything. And... And I'd understand. I'm... I'm. I was never any good at... at this part. The... The stuff that happens if you... don't run."
Dakota 3/16/2023 11:31 PM
Kaleva tensed, his eyes narrowing further, a growing suspicion crawling up his spine and making the stripe of hair bristle up anew as he looked more sharply, more critically at the man's features. His voice had gone flat and hollow when he next spoke. "And why would you have any interest in me."
Daarka 3/16/2023 11:35 PM
The man's features... certainly seemed to have some similarities to what Kaleva saw in the mirror. "... Because I... I left before you were born," he managed with no small effort after a moment, his gaze now anywhere but on Kaleva's face. "And I... always... hated myself for it. Always... had a part of me that... wished I could... do something about it." He swallowed thickly, his gaze dropping to his boots. "... You're the... only child I've ever had."
Dakota 3/16/2023 11:43 PM
Small, flinching twitches could be seen around Kaleva's teal-green eyes, his scarred features tight and tense, every muscle in his body locked up, teeth gritted. It was hard to say if he was processing, or if he'd shut down. The silence stretched on for an uncomfortably long time. Even his tail had gone still, held low to the ground and frozen in a tight curl near his legs. All he could hear was static in his ears. All he could feel was the heavy thud of his heart, as he felt cold, like all the blood was rushing out of his limbs, and he could suddenly feel the bitter cold that he was normally comfortable with.
Daarka 3/16/2023 11:48 PM
Skena knew Kaleva, more than anyone else on the planet. And so it didn't take more than a second or two of him existing in that state before the magic on her fingertips took form, and she placed a soft touch to his back, offering a wash of soothing calm over him if he chose to give in to it. Simultaneously, she pushed herself up to stand more alongside him in the doorway, seizing the awkward lapse of pseudo-conversation as the person (marginally) least affected by it all to speak up--since Ludin was turtling in on himself and looking like he certainly didn't have the spine to break the silence. "This is sudden, as I'm sure you understand. I know this is rude, but please give us a moment." Without waiting for consent from the hornless tiefling, she neatly and fairly calmly shut the door on him, gently trying to guide Kaleva back a few steps so he could breathe and process and speak a bit more freely to her if he needed to, her hands lightly resting on either of his arms and her eyes on his face, watching him with compassion and concern.
Dakota 3/16/2023 11:58 PM
Even with the calming magic, Kaleva had gone mute. He allowed himself to be led away from the door, but he barely seemed to see her even as she stood in front of him. He reached up and grasped around his collarbone, searching for the amulet of Anubis that he wore, that was presently resting on the night stand when he took it off to sleep. But not finding it there, his hand limply dropped again, the scimitars dangling dangerously limp from the other. Even so, even without the amulet, he turned his gaze to the shrine and drew strength from that. Whoever this man was standing outside the door, he may have had a biological hand in his creation, but Anubis and his spiritual hand had guided him since he was small, and guided him to this day. Had accepted him and loved him and called him his son. He took in a deep, shuddering breath, and clarity gradually returned to his features, shifting his attention to Skena. He gave her a brief little nod and went to set aside the scimitars, turning to return to the door, opening it and wordlessly gesturing Ludin inside.
Daarka 3/17/2023 12:05 AM
Skena seemed to follow him through every step of that wordless journey, her own gaze silently reassuring as he finally looked to her. When he seemed to be more grounded, she let her hands fall away from him, stepping aside to allow him to move as he pleased. When he opened the door again, Ludin looked... a little dejected. Perhaps understandably so. It was the look of a man who knew he deserved no warm welcome, but was still ill-equipped to look the consequences of his actions in the eye. As the door opened again, Ludin seemed to brace himself for some sort of vitriol--but when none came, he finally looked up again, staring blankly at the gesture for him to come inside. It took him a long moment to digest that it was, in fact, directed at him, and very uncertainly, he took a few halting steps forward, before walking the rest of the way inside as Kaleva did not stop his advance. As this happened, Skena had briefly stooped down to where Gummy had trotted over to her heels, reaching to take something from his mouth before the little minion made himself scarce. As she straightened up again, she subtly shifted to press Kaleva's missing amulet into the palm of his hand. "... Would you like me to go put on the coffee pot?" She asked softly, the question directed at Kaleva exclusively. (edited)
Dakota 3/17/2023 12:11 AM
"..Yeah. Please." Kaleva took the amulet, squeezing it in his palm to feel its reassuring shape, then slid it on over his head and let the comforting weight of it ground him. The huskies were still keeping their distance, and Atreyu stood over them like a protective older brother, watching the newcomer warily. The tiefling turned to Ludin, gesturing with a motion of his head for him to follow as he went to the living room fireplace, tossing a few logs into the fireplace and setting up kindling to get a fire going. "So how'd you find out about me?" He glanced back at Ludin as he crouched in front of the fire, making sure it caught. "My name, my location, that I was even alive."
Daarka 3/17/2023 12:20 AM
Skena nodded, scurrying to the kitchen to get coffee brewing, while keeping an eye and an ear on the conversation. Ludin stood awkwardly off to the side, somehow looking out of place in the cozy cabin. "... I think... maybe... fifteen years ago now...? Maybe less... It's... been hard to keep track. That was the... the first time I was back in Holbrook since... since I... got out. Before you were born. Couldn't really help but... try to ask around. Try to... to see what ever became of Marian's baby. If I'm being honest... really expected them to have done away with you early on. But she was... I don't know. I didn't think her the... I guess... the baby-killing type." He drifted off a moment, briefly lost in thought, before continuing. "... Managed to pick up some rumor about Marian's secret demon or whatnot," he went on--spoken as someone for whom such crude language had been normalized around him for decades. "Somethin' about him escaping. Guess I... didn't really expect that. Made me realize how much I'd been... hoping for something like that, though. Tried my best to sort out where you would have gone off to." He was quiet a moment, before adding, softer, "Search kind of ended with Marko." (edited)
Dakota 3/17/2023 12:34 AM
There were a lot of cruel things Kaleva could have said. Described living in the basement, nameless, sleeping on a pile of dirty rags on a hard dirt floor, with only a bucket as a latrine, his only contact with his mother being her opening the door to throw down food or set in a bucket of water and occasionally swap out his latrine once a week or so. And the occasional visit of her timid friend, who tried to do the right thing despite being terrified of him, who gave him paper and paints and the occasional other odd thing to play with. He was tempted, at first. Tempted to just unleash the toxicity of his experiences on this man. To blame him for it all. But with a sigh, he found he couldn't muster the hate. It sucked being a tiefling. Especially a tiefling in Holbrook. He didn't know Ludin's exact circumstances. That he was here at all said something, even if it was too little, too late. "I got out when I was... probably somewhere around ten or twelve, by Marko's guess. He found me, took me in." He didn't mention the villagers hunting for him and wanting him dead, or the death of the little girl. Chances are, if Ludin had heard about 'Marian's secret demon,' he probably heard the rest of it. "He gave me my name, taught me how to survive. Hunters got him when I was somewhere around seventeen, so I took off and left Holbrook."
Daarka 3/17/2023 12:37 AM
Ludin listened in perfect silence, swallowing a few times as if to try to ward off a pervasively dry mouth. "... What was the name Marko gave you...?" He asked after a moment, his words tentative, like he wasn't entirely sure he had a right to be asking any questions at all.
Dakota 3/17/2023 12:40 AM
He pushed himself up to stand once the fire was going steadily, bringing a soft, golden light to the room. "Kaleva." Looking over at the dogs, he went to reassure them, rubbing at their ears and murmuring quiet words of comfort. Song and Finch were still cautious, still sensed the tension in the air, but at Kaleva's gentle command they went back to lay down on the bed. Atreyu stayed nearby though, and went to lay down in front of the fire, his pumpkin orange eyes watching Ludin.
Daarka 3/17/2023 12:45 AM
Ludin digested that name for a while, watching Kaleva--his son--go tend to his animals. And not missing the tiny corpse-woman who had come to stand in the entryway to the kitchen as the coffee brewed, observing everything wordlessly. He remained standing, not looking like he had even considered making himself comfortable. "... Kaleva." A long beat. "That's a good name." Another pause. "... Better than anything I would have come up with." He swallowed yet again, slowly drawing in a tight breath. "Then. Kaleva... I'm sorry. Nothing I say will ever be enough. I don't... I don't know what this life has been like for you. But I know enough to be sorry. In... In a way I don't think I can ever wash myself of." His jaw clenched briefly again. "... And you don't have to accept that apology, either. But... I think... the only thing worse than what I've done... would be to not be sorry for it."
Dakota 3/17/2023 12:58 AM
"...I don't need your apology," he said with a shrug. Not cruelly, just with indifference. "I don't know you. Marko offered to tell me about what he knew of you, but I wasn't interested in knowing. There was a time that I resented the idea of you, once I was taught what parents were typically supposed to be, but... Mmn. I had other things to worry about. And it seems like you did, too." He hadn't been quite sure why he was humoring Ludin at first. Curiosity, perhaps. Some answers to questions he'd long since given up on ever getting. But as they talked, the indifference lingered. He started to realize that whether or not he got answers... didn't really matter that much to him. Talking with Ludin, letting him learn about his son, affected Ludin way more than it did him. Benefitted him more. And that... was okay. It didn't cost him anything, if it brought Ludin some peace.
Daarka 3/17/2023 1:06 AM
The man nodded slowly, almost a little haltingly as he digested that response. It wasn't sunshine and rainbows, but... it wasn't unbridled vitriol, either. Even though he couldn't help but ache for the former, he knew he didn't deserve it. He was silent for a while, his gaze eventually roaming the space around them. "... Your home is beautiful. And you... you seem well," he ventured cautiously, his gaze lingering momentarily on the statue of Anubis. Then he seemed to become aware of Skena staring directly at him as he did so, and he dropped his gaze again.
Dakota 3/17/2023 8:10 AM
"Thanks," Kaleva said, gesturing to the couch in invitation. "Been doing a lot better in the last couple years. Skena and I built this place together, once we found a place where we could just... be, and not be hated for it. Don't know if you've dared venture close to Fielbarry, but there's a pretty sizeable tiefling population, and tiefling-run businesses. Many other marginalized races, too." He perched himself on the arm of the couch halfway, one leg tucked up over it, the other bracing himself on the floor, his heavily-scarred arms folded. "You seem like you've had a rough time of things, too."
Daarka 3/17/2023 12:29 PM
Ludin hesitated a moment, before slowly, gingerly, stepping over to take a seat where directed. Instead of sitting back and getting comfortable, though, he simply leaned forward to prop his elbows on his knees in a... subtly familiar posture. "Ah... I tend to stay out of towns," he said softly, sounding like--despite Kaleva's promising description of Fielbarry--he might have been a bit stuck in the rut of prior experiences. At his last comment, he didn't meet his gaze, almost ducking his head a little. "... It's all, ah. I did it all to myself," he managed awkwardly, his words faint. A pause, before he clumsily added, "Not... Not this," with a weak gesture towards the barely-healed gash across the lower side of his face and neck. "I mean the... the horns and such." He didn't look back up at Kaleva, silent for a few seconds, before quietly continuing, "... They used to... look a lot like yours. Little... uncanny, really..."
Dakota 3/17/2023 1:30 PM
His eyes widened with horror as he came to realize the... depths of desperation that Ludin must have felt, to... To shear off his own horns. "...Why?" It was almost a whisper.
Daarka 3/17/2023 1:42 PM
It wasn't just his horns, Kaleva would realize a moment later. He had seen no sign of a tail, either. Ludin still looked meek as he was silent a moment, before a hand lifted to reach into the collar of his shirt, pulling out a small amulet. His fingers moved in a brief but deliberate pattern against its surface, and with a quick blur, the grey-skinned, mutilated tiefling seemed to be replaced with a man of the exact same build, exact same hairstyle and color, but a more humanoid, copper complexion to his skintone, and eyes of a dull grey--but with typical white sclera and a black pupil within. Across his forehead, the two clear markings where the root of his horns had been was replaced with a very precise design of scarring, as if something had struck and burned him diagonally from the top of his crown, down over the opposite brow ridge, even ending a little on the cheek bone below. But that illusory scarring in no way suggested there had ever been the presence of horns beneath. Even his ears remained the exact same size and shape, making him suddenly look like some manner of half-elf. "... Didn't have magic available that... truly changes anything." He ran his hand through the empty space over his forehead where horns should have protruded from. "Before... I'd still look like this, but... all it'd take is one bad brush, one clumsy mistake. And an invisible horn or tail would give me away. Was... It was serviceable for a while. Just didn't get close to anyone." There was a long pause as he chewed faintly at the inside of his lip. "... Things changed when... I just..." He looked embarrassed--more than that, he looked humiliated, his hand shifting to slowly rub the back of his neck. "... Didn't want to keep my distance from Marian."
1:44 PM
As the amulet was produced and used, Skena's eyes honed in on it from where she stood a little ways off. Ludin didn't seem to notice as she very subtly cast a spell, though there was no overt effect from it, and she stayed silent, only moving again to push away from the wall and go pour the coffee as she heard it finishing.
Dakota 3/17/2023 2:05 PM
Kaleva ran his hands through his hair, taking in the appearance of Ludin's more humanoid disguise, quietly stricken. Any lingering resentment faded, couldn't find any sort of foothold in his heart. Because Ludin was another victim of the tiefling experience, the hatred that so much of this world had for their kind. He'd permanently mutilated himself just so he could hide more efficiently. He couldn't even fault him for having gotten close to his mother, because he knew how lonely their existence could be, and how desperate one could become for a kind word and a gentle touch. Any sort of experience that didn't involve fear and pain. "I get it," he said quietly. "I understand how lonely that kind of existence is." He went quiet for a bit, then offered, "...I can help build you a home nearby, if you want. You don't have to keep running."
Daarka 3/17/2023 4:24 PM
Ludin blinked a few times, looking over to Kaleva with a blank look of surprise‚Äîwhich was quickly overrun by something ashamed and awkward as he shook his head, dropping the illusion and returning to his natural appearance. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ You don‚Äôt owe me anything. Any kindness. I‚Äôve. I‚Äôve done nothing to help your life.‚Äù His halting babbling was cut off as Skena reappeared with a warm mug in each hand, handing one to Kaleva and offering the other to Ludin. Her face was a bit unreadable, but not unkind. The man hesitated, not looking any more willing to accept the coffee than the offer of a free house. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no burden to us for you to drink our coffee,‚Äù Skena murmured evenly. ‚ÄúWe have sugar and cream if you‚Äôd like it, too.‚Äù Ludin seemed to be trying not to squirm where he sat, but ultimately reached to gingerly receive the mug, with a faint mumble of, ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Black is fine. Thank you.‚Äù
Dakota 3/17/2023 5:00 PM
"Thanks," he murmured to Skena, and sipped at his own, cradling the warmth in his hands. "It's not about owing you anything. It's an offer, freely given. It's about... giving us both an opportunity. You, to have a place of safety and of home, which should be a basic right for anyone... And for us to maybe build a relationship. It'd be far enough away that we'd both have our space and privacy, but within reasonable traveling distance." He wasn't about to offer some stranger a house next door like Cass and Nils had with their parents. He still very much wanted his space. But helping Ludin set something up a mile or two away? Yeah, he could do that. "Anyway, the offer's there if you ever want it. But don't feel obligated to if you don't."
Daarka 3/17/2023 5:06 PM
The free home, Ludin could live without. He certainly had for most of his life up to now. It was the offer of a chance to build a relationship with his only son that gave him pause. He stared down into the coffee in his hands for a moment, swallowing again. "... I think I'd... I'd like that," he managed faintly. "... Thank you." He seemed lost in thought a moment, before remembering himself, and hastily adding, "I-I can try to help, I--I've never built something big like that before, but you... you shouldn't have to do all the work." Once the coffee was handed off, Skena stepped away again, only to delicately sit herself down on the couch up against Kaleva's leg where he sat on the arm, as if to--subconsciously or otherwise--place herself passively between the two men, taking the opportunity provided by Ludin's chronically lowered gaze to prod over him with her own.
Dakota 3/17/2023 5:18 PM
"I can show you how," Kaleva said with a shrug, his tail shifting around to tuck around Skena, the tufted tip resting in her lap. "I'm self-taught, but still managed to build this place." His gaze unfocused as he sipped at his coffee, staring into the fire and how it played off the orange in Atreyu's fur. "You said the search came to a halt at Marko's. How did you find me here?"
Daarka 3/17/2023 5:40 PM
Ludin nodded slowly, looking around a little a second time to take in the cottage once more. "... That... That visit to Holbrook, fifteen years back, or whenever it was... I got word from a... an ally of sorts that Marko had taken in a little tiefling boy. Folks who knew me... at least, what... what I really look like--they could put two and two together. Went to go to his place." A pause. "Found him. Would'a been after you left, I guess." The hollow look in his eyes, heavily steeped in shame, made it seem like that turn of events was something he likely also blamed himself for. "... He was a good man," he mumbled after a while. Silence stretched on again, before he gradually continued. "... But you weren't there with him. I... had to hope you got out in one piece. Didn't know where to begin looking, though. Spent the next... however long just... keeping an eye out. Wasn't until... maybe sometime this past fall, I heard word of some traveling group of folks. Somethin' about it was... noteworthy, I guess, had folks gossiping about it all. There was a mention of a couple... pretty unique individuals. Some kind of lizardfolk... don't really get those up north, even south of the Holbrekkan border. And a tiefling, with grey skin, black hair, and teal eyes." If there had also been gossip about a tiny corpse woman, Ludin appeared to be consciously not repeating those details. "Had my attention... I asked around, found someone who'd seen this lot more directly. Had them describe your horns." He shrugged a little, meekly. "Could have been a coincidence. Didn't think it was, though. Still, I... I couldn't pick up the trail again. Ended up just... drifting around, trying to find something without knowing what I was after." A beat. "Sometime in the winter... I... caught wind of a lizardfolk up in Laracus, traveling in a group with a tiefling. Not... Not the same tiefling, but... it was... too specific to ignore. Managed to follow them that time. Back to here." (edited)
Dakota 3/17/2023 9:22 PM
Kaleva let out a hum, his face a bit grim, likely not particularly pleased with how much people apparently took notice of him when he was out on missions. "...Probably goes without saying, but I'd appreciate if you didn't spread word about where we live. A few people know, but they're people we know we can trust." Something was tickling at his thoughts, and he remembered Yiska's mention of the scent of wolf on him. He tipped his head and considered Ludin thoughtfully. "...Odd question, but. Do you like wolves?"
Daarka 3/17/2023 9:25 PM
Ludin nodded easily at the request, pausing at his question. He squinted a little--not in a guarded way, but clearly trying to ascertain where that had come from. "... Bit of an odd question, I guess. Wolves are... Wolves are wolves, I suppose. Met some that gave me a hard time, met some that didn't." A beat, as he glanced towards where the huskies had tottered off to. "... If you've got one around or something, I don't mind, if that's what you're asking for."
Dakota 3/17/2023 9:30 PM
"Sort of. One of our friends described your scent as carrying the scent of wolves in a way like you were affiliated with some. I wasn't sure if that meant you had one as a companion, or what." The pieces were starting to click together in his mind. The group that went to Laracus, the mission he specifically was told not to take part in, because of this cult of Fenrir and how they were apparently swaying members of the Order of the Lycan. And Ludin following them back. It seemed too coincidental.
Daarka 3/17/2023 9:35 PM
Ludin shook his head a little. "... Got nothing against wolves, I guess. The... normal ones, anyways." His gaze had wandered off, back to looking a little hollow as he chewed over that topic. "... Some things like to look like wolves, though. Guess it's a... pretty popular way for some awful things to present themselves. What's the phrase... wolf in sheep's clothing?" He shook his head a little. "Don't think I mind wolves, whether they want to wear sheep hide or not. Pretty tired of... Hell comin' in wolf's clothing, though." A beat, before he rather tiredly continued. "... I'm sure I do have some sort of lingering scent. Seems everything wants to stick to me."
Dakota 3/17/2023 9:54 PM
"Hell in wolf's clothing?" Kaleva echoed slowly. "What does that mean? Are you talking about werewolves?"
Daarka 3/17/2023 9:56 PM
He blinked, glancing over to him briefly before dropping his gaze again, shaking his head. "No. I mean it plainly. Demons in the shape of wolves."
Dakota 3/17/2023 10:01 PM
Kaleva chewed at the inside of his cheek, clawed nails tapping lightly against the ceramic mug. "How'd you manage to get tangled up in that?"
Daarka 3/17/2023 10:09 PM
Skena might not have blinked in the last ten consecutive minutes, her gaze raking over every detail of the man in front of her while her back stayed pressed against Kaleva's leg, hands neatly resting over his tail in her lap. Though her expression managed to stay empty as she listened along, not betraying trust nor suspicion. Ludin didn't respond immediately, some of that shame seeming to creep back in again around the edges. In a subconscious but small movement, he shifted the coffee mug he held to one hand instead of being balanced between both, freeing the other to turn in and absentmindedly rub at a spot on his wrist. "... Same reason as everything else, I guess. Desperation." He paused, before seeming to remember himself, glancing briefly back over to Kaleva again. "... I don't mean to imply I'm... bringing trouble to your door. That's not the case. It's all... It's... I'm... I've been trying to put it behind me for years. Done about all I can on that front. Maybe whatever's left is just... something I'll have to carry to my grave."
Dakota 3/17/2023 10:23 PM
He tilted his head slightly, studying Ludin consideringly. "...Blackswords?" he guessed, one brow raising slightly.
Daarka 3/17/2023 10:25 PM
Ludin stiffened slightly, looking back to him. This time, holding his gaze properly, a look of surprise, wariness... and a little bit of curiosity on his face. Or maybe bewilderment. "... More or less," he finally responded after a long silence. "... I didn't... have the impression they were... down this far south...?"
Dakota 3/17/2023 10:32 PM
"A couple of them attacked my group - the one you originally heard about near the border, while we were out on a mission. Werewolves, with the symbols of the Blackswords tattooed on their chests. They were pretty fixated on me in particular, for some reason." He met Ludin's gaze, his own calm and neutral, leaving the character evaluation in Skena's hands. That was her wheelhouse more than his. "I have my suspicions why, but if you had any sort of insight on that, I'd appreciate it."
Daarka 3/17/2023 10:47 PM
That understanding looked to ease back some of his wary confusion--and as his brows relaxed from the furrow they had crept towards, it certainly looked as though his wariness was not for some secret being uncovered... but some fear that this entity had not been left behind in the north. He drew in a long breath, sighing it out slowly. "... What's that word for... things like genetics, that get passed down between generations...?" "Hereditary traits?" Skena offered softly. Ludin blinked at her rare interjection, before nodding a little. "Yeah. It's funny... in the way that doesn't make you laugh. A mother has pale blonde hair, but her mate's is dark. Their child's hair is some shade in between. That child grows up and has babies with someone else with dark hair. The original mother's grandchildren scarcely have a single pale hair on their heads. It all... waters down like that. Pretty quick, too." He fell quiet. Seemed to remember the coffee he was holding, and raised it for a small sip. "But if that mother was a tiefling, the child and all the grandchildren are tieflings, too. Not much getting around that. The bloodline becomes permanently stained that color. The grandchildren may have dark hair... but they'll be just as much tieflings as their grandma. The infernal doesn't get watered down. Wish it would. Had hoped it would. Even if you were damned to have horns and a tail, I... I guess a part of me always hoped that wherever you were... whatever struggles you faced... the blood of a human woman would have watered down my own. Just so you had... one less thing breathing down your neck." He swallowed, tiredly looking down into his coffee. "... Been told I'm a demonspawn my whole life. That wasn't new. People who say that don't think much about the words, they just sound good and nasty. But someone told me what demon I was descended from. Didn't say it like a curse. Said it like it was a blessing. Don't know who wouldn't at least be a little curious about that... I heard them out. When I was desperate... I heard the demon out, too. Not proud of that," he added quietly, certainly sounding ashamed, "... but it is what it is now."
Dakota 3/17/2023 10:54 PM
"Fenrir," Kaleva confirmed with a small nod. "Yeah, that confirms it." He sighed, taking a long sip of his coffee. "If you ever need safety from them, you can ask for my help. It's not just for personal reasons - it's what I do. I'm a blood hunter, we fight monsters, and that includes fiends."
Daarka 3/17/2023 10:58 PM
"You--sorry, I don't mean to interrupt," Skena piped up quietly. "Um. You keep using the word demon specifically. Whoever was knowledgeable enough to tell you these things about yourself--that's the word they used, too? Not devil, or fiend, or... something more wild like Baatezu?" Ludin had been a little dumbstruck by Kaleva's response, but paused at Skena's question. "... Demon was the only word I ever heard. Sometimes fiend... I... I guess sometimes hellspawn or the sort. Can't recall hearing those others, though." Skena gave a simple, wordless nod, not asking anything further. Ludin hesitated, before looking back to Kaleva. "... You're a blood hunter...?"
Dakota 3/17/2023 11:06 PM
Kaleva was still sitting there in just his pajama pants, and wordlessly lifted his scarred arms in confirmation - though the gesture also flashed the burn-scar on the inside of his wrist that he received as a mark from having served time in prison. Skena's interjection did have him giving her a curious look though, because... yeah. He was familiar with her whole argument of demon versus devil. "Figured if I'm already getting a bad reputation from being a tiefling, being a blood hunter isn't really going to make things any worse. I like what they stand for. Blood magic has a stigma against it, sure, but the aims of the Orders are to use that magic to protect people."
Daarka 3/17/2023 11:10 PM
Ludin looked over the scarring, giving a slow nod at his explanation. "... That sounds... noble." He sounded a little caught off guard, but... potentially in a good way. The adjective he used did not come across like a substitute for a less kind word, but like quiet, unexpected reverence.
Dakota 3/17/2023 11:22 PM
"Mm." He made a bit of a face at the word. "I guess. Never was a fan of the word. I just figure the world's shitty enough without innocent folk having to deal with monsters... And it gives me a productive outlet when I'm feeling angry at the world in general."
Daarka 3/17/2023 11:28 PM
He seemed to chew on whatever words were bouncing through his head for a moment, before settling on, "I'm... I'm happy for you then. It'd... It'd feel wrong to say I'm proud of you. None of that had anything to do with something I did for you. None of it is anything I deserve to carry on my own name like that. But... If I had done right by you... If I'd... been an actual father... I'm sure proud is what that'd make me. I think it's... it's easy to cause harm. Lot harder to do good."
Dakota 3/17/2023 11:52 PM
Kaleva blinked, his expression softening a little bit, the corner of his mouth twitching into the first semi-smile he'd shown since Ludin had arrived. "...Thanks. I haven't always done the right thing. It's... hard to make the right choices when you live with the kind of stigma that we do. And we don't always get the luxury of being able to do good." He reached up and fingered his amulet, thumbing over the scarab nestled in the loop of the ankh, and glancing to Skena with a wider smile. "I've had a bit of help, though."
Daarka 3/18/2023 12:00 AM
Ludin looked over at that, his gaze traveling to the little aasimar. ‚ÄúI see that‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ want to be presumptuous of your relation‚Ä¶‚Äù Skena‚Äôs cheeks darkened ever so slightly, but she maintained her dignity. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ We don‚Äôt really have a word for our relationship,‚Äù she offered softly. ‚ÄúIt just is. Soulmates comes pretty close, I guess.‚Äù She politely extended a hand towards him. ‚ÄúI suppose I didn‚Äôt properly introduce myself, either. My name‚Äôs Skena. It‚Äôs good to meet you.‚Äù Ludin looked like‚Ä¶ maybe, once he‚Äôd had time to digest all of this later and sleep on it, he‚Äôd be overwhelmed by it all. His son was alive, healthy, thriving, a property owner and resident of a self-built home, was gainfully employed with honorable people doing heroic work to better the world, and even had a‚Äîwell. Some vague semblance of a significant other. He hadn‚Äôt earned any right to be proud of Kaleva, but it was getting hard to temper that reflex. He reached out after a pause to return Skena‚Äôs handshake, giving a small dip of his chin. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Is it‚Ä¶ too personal to ask how you met‚Ä¶?‚Äù (edited)
Dakota 3/18/2023 7:16 AM
He shook his head. "No, it's fine. After I fled from Holbrook, I kept traveling further south-east. Marko had said that he'd heard people were more tolerant of tieflings the further south you went, so I just... kept going, until I wound up in Cusai. They wouldn't kill a tiefling on sight there, but there was definitely discrimination. No one would let me exchange labor for food or anything, so I had to steal. Got caught, and was beaten for it. Broken tail and some bruised ribs I think. Skena found me licking my wounds and healed me, offered to give me a place to stay at the temple of Anubis where she lived."
Daarka 3/18/2023 11:41 AM
Ludin nodded slowly as he listened, still loosely postured as if curled around the mug he now held ever so slightly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm happy for you. Never been to the desert myself‚Ä¶ seems to have worked out alright for you in the end, though.‚Äù
Dakota 3/20/2023 8:39 AM
"The desert is a bit too hot for me," Kaleva said with a half smile. "But yeah. We had some trouble, the people at the temple didn't approve of my presence or my friendship with Skena, so... Well. To make a long story short, I was framed, sentenced to death in the arena, and by the grace of Anubis and Skena, managed to get away with my life and a banishment. We were separated for nearly a decade before we found each other again."
Daarka 3/20/2023 12:01 PM
Whereas most who heard this story were horrified by the details, Ludin did not seem remotely surprised. Quietly sympathetic, perhaps, but the horror of it was no shock to him. He did, however, give Kaleva a faintly strange look as he continued. He glanced briefly to the girl--that was Skena--and then his gaze wandered to... the massive dog in front of the fire? "... Is this Anubis, then?"
Dakota 3/20/2023 12:12 PM
Atreyu perked his ears up at Ludin, his tail thumping on the floor, though he kept his chin on his folded forelegs. Kaleva chuckled softly in surprise. "Oh, no, his name is Atreyu. Anubis is the god of funerary rites and protector of graves. He weighs the hearts of the dead to judge the weight of their sins and ushers their souls to the afterlife." He gestured to the shrine Ludin had been looking at earlier.
Daarka 3/20/2023 12:15 PM
Ludin followed his gesture to look back to the shrine, understanding shifting on his features. "Oh." He looked over that statue a moment longer, taking in the features now that he knew what it represented, before his attention shifted back to Atreyu. "... So... um." He opened and closed his mouth a few times, staring blankly at the massive dog as he tried to figure out what exactly the question was he wanted to ask and how to phrase it.
Dakota 3/20/2023 12:22 PM
Kaleva tilted his head slightly at Ludin's gaping, taking pity on him after giving him a chance to figure out what he wanted to say. "Haven't seen a dog like him before? He's a Cautican hound, bred specifically in Cautica as a riding mount. They're highly intelligent and can understand Common. Much longer lived than normal dogs too. He'll probably live as long as I do if something doesn't take me before old age does."
Daarka 3/20/2023 12:25 PM
That seemed to answer his question, his head tilting ever so slightly as he looked the hound over. "... He's a... normal beast, then? Just... unusually... large...?" Skena had been smiling slightly as she listened along, and she cocked her head slightly at that. "As opposed to...?" Ludin paused, glancing back at her, before giving a meek shrug. "... I've seen wolves unusually big like that. They just... weren't... natural." (edited)
Dakota 3/20/2023 12:31 PM
Kaleva's brow furrowed. "You mean dire wolves? They're not common, but I don't know that I'd call them unnatural."
Daarka 3/20/2023 12:33 PM
Ludin shook his head a little. "... Still talkin' about demons," he mumbled tiredly. "I've seen dire wolves. Never any as big as..." "Atreyu," Skena offered. "Atreyu. Didn't know... wolves--or dogs, I suppose--got bigger without... something else in the mix."
Dakota 3/20/2023 12:39 PM
"Oh... Hmm. Well, if they have anything to do with Fenrir, I shouldn't be surprised." He finished his coffee and leaned forward to set the empty mug on the coffee table. "I think technically Cautican hounds were bred with something fey?" He posed the sort-of question to Skena. "If I remember correctly." Atreyu had grown more comfortable with Ludin's presence the more Kaleva and Skena seemed to accept him, and seeing the man so weary, he scooted forward on his belly to nose up under Ludin's hands for pets.
Daarka 3/20/2023 12:44 PM
‚ÄúPossibly, I didn‚Äôt research them that deep when I lived there; I didn‚Äôt realize I‚Äôd be investing in one until long after leaving.‚Äù Ludin froze as Atreyu wiggled closer, not quite recoiling, but seeming to lock up like a prey animal as he tried to gauge what the massive dog was doing. When he nosed under his hand and seemed to be making his intentions clear, Ludin‚Ä¶ slowly moved again, hesitantly petting over his snout. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Seems nice enough, at least,‚Äù he mumbled distractedly, almost looking a little dazed with the interaction.
Dakota 3/20/2023 12:50 PM
Kaleva's eyes softened, smiling at the two. "He's a love bug. As soon as he figures you're someone safe, he starts trying to make friends. He's still a puppy, too." Pets accomplished, Atreyu chinned in Ludin's lap and gazed up at him with those soulful eyes, one paw lifting to tuck a mantis leg over his thighs, clearly getting comfortable.
Daarka 3/20/2023 3:01 PM
"... How much bigger is he going to get?" Ludin murmured, almost warily at the implications. He looked a little awkward as Atreyu helped himself into his lap, carefully moving his coffee so it didn't get compromised.
Dakota 3/20/2023 8:47 PM
"Not much, I don't think. He's mostly grown physically, it'd just be muscle mass. But he's always going to be pretty lanky. Cautican hounds are sight hounds, so they're built for speed." Kaleva smiled a bit, watching Atreyu schmooze up to Ludin. "Skena got him as a gift for me. He was about the size of a colt when she brought him home. He was all legs, gangly and awkward."
Daarka 3/20/2023 8:56 PM
"Still is..." Ludin murmured a bit wryly, slowly running his fingers over the soft fur on Atreyu's forehead. "Surprised he hasn't frozen to death..." "Us desert creatures very nearly do this time of year," Skena replied amusedly. "But we manage. Tre just spends less time outside in the winter. He's built for speed and endurance, so he doesn't have much natural insulation so he won't overheat while exerting himself. Which just means when it gets cold out, he turns into a bit of a blanket gremlin."
Dakota 3/20/2023 9:09 PM
"He also has horse blankets and booties. Well - I made him booties, but he really doesn't like wearing them. Starts staggering around like he's drunk. I think he's baffled by the huskies, too. Half the time they don't even want to sleep in the bedroom with us, they'd rather be outside in the snow." Kaleva snorted. "He used to try ushering them inside and couldn't understand why they resisted." Atreyu's lips were curled up into a smile, his eyes squinting closed while Ludin petted him. People were talking about him, and while they weren't saying the most flattering things, these things were spoken of with affection, and so he was happy.
Daarka 3/20/2023 9:17 PM
"Never really known any breeds of dog that can't handle the snow. Glad he's got a warm bed, though," Ludin said softly, his demeanor... still a bit stiff, clearly unaccustomed to such moments, but still doing his best to stick it out and not be spooked off by it. He was quiet a moment, before glancing over to Kaleva meekly. "... You've been... more accommodating to me than I deserve," he said, softer. "Is there... anything I can do for you? Do you... have questions for me?"
Dakota 3/20/2023 9:21 PM
Kaleva considered for a minute, a little furrow to his brow. "...I'll probably have more questions when I've had time to fully process everything. Right now I'm kind of going through an adrenaline crash and I'm getting drowsy." As if to punctuate his words, he muffed a yawn behind his fist. "But I don't want to kick you back out into the cold, either. You're welcome to crash on the couch if you want. We have extra pillows and blankets."
Daarka 3/20/2023 9:30 PM
Ludin quickly shook his head. "No, I--I won't occupy your house. You don't... You don't know me. I'm little more than a stranger. I'm fine, I'm used to... making do in Holbrook and Laracus. It's plenty warm down here." "Are you sure? Can we at least send you off with a spare blanket?" Skena offered gently. Ludin hesitated, clearly very unused to such offerings. A free house, a relationship with the son who deserved better than him for a father, extended hospitality from people he startled awake, free coffee... and now a blanket. "... I... It's--" "I insist," Skena decided, getting to her feet. "It'll put my conscious to rest that you have what you need to ward off the cold and we're not just sending you out to freeze in the woods. You don't even have to really use it, but it's no bother to me to part with it; I can easily go replace it tomorrow. It'll be yours to keep." She headed off to the bedroom to fish out a spare blanket--of which they had several--leaving the tieflings on the couch, one of them mildly uncomfortable and a bit slack-jawed and wide-eyed.
Dakota 3/20/2023 9:39 PM
Kaleva sent Ludin a bit of a lopsided smirk of amusement at his bamboozlement. "Better start getting used to it if you're going to stick around. I know you're probably used to gestures of kindness coming with conditions or having it held over your head later, but you won't get that from us. We and our neighbors have a sort of support system that we just... help each other out, even if it's not really needed. Excess goods and supplies are shared with each other without expectation of anything in return."
Daarka 3/20/2023 9:46 PM
Ludin didn't respond immediately, looking over as Skena returned with a maroon blanket that looked delightfully plush, with one side being thickly woven wool that looked like it could probably handle some rough exposure, while the other side was exceptionally soft cotton stuffed with fluffy down that looked delightfully cozy. She pushed it into his hands, gently nudging Atreyu's big noggin aside so he could stand. "There. If you like it, keep it. If you find it unnecessary, feel free to sell it in town--which is southeast of here--and keep the coin." Ludin slowly got to his feet, looking over the thick bundle of fabric a moment, before dipping his chin a little. "... Thank you. That's... very kind. I'll... I'll be on my way, let you two get back to bed."
Dakota 3/20/2023 9:55 PM
Atreyu got up as he was nudged aside, turning to trot off into the bedroom. Kaleva stood and went to gather up the coffee mugs, giving Ludin a thoughtful stare. "...It took a lot of guts to come here. Especially having no idea of what the outcome would be. But I'm glad you did. If you want to swing by in the afternoon or whenever, we'll be around..." He trailed off as Atreyu came back out of the bedroom with one of his stuffed animals in his mouth - a rabbit, made of actual rabbit fur, with large black button eyes and stuffed with cotton. The hound then proceeded to drop it on top of the blanket in Ludin's arms, gave him a boof, and then went to trot back into the bedroom.
Daarka 3/20/2023 9:58 PM
Ludin stared blankly at the rabbit toy, and Skena fought hard not to let a grin split across her face. He started to reach to pick it up and hesitantly offer it back to Skena, but she quickly shook her head. "Nono, that's evidently his gift to you as well. Best hang on to that." "... Right." It was gingerly returned to the top of the fold of blankets, and he looked back to Kaleva. "... I'm... I'm glad I did, too," he replied quietly. "... Thank you for the coffee. And... supplies..." A pause, before he gave another awkward nod, and turned to head back towards the door. "... Have a good night, then."
Dakota 3/20/2023 10:08 PM
"You too, Ludin." After the other tiefling left, Kaleva closed the door and went to bring the used mugs to the sink, setting them in to wash in the morning. Dishes were a problem for future Kaleva. "...What's your take on him?" he asked Skena at length. He knew his opinions on his biological father, but the reservations would remain until he got Skena's insight, which he trusted far more than his own.
Daarka 3/20/2023 10:10 PM
Skena took a deep breath, following him into the kitchen. "... You first? Just... how are you feeling? Net positive? Net negative?" She replied, tipping her head to meet his gaze with gentle compassion.
Dakota 3/20/2023 10:16 PM
"Net positive, I guess." He turned to lean against the counter, arms folded tightly. "A few years ago I think I would have met his attempts with vitriol, drove him away with harsh words. But I can't find it in me to hate him, or to even be upset with his decisions. I look at him and I see a man who has been beaten down and cowed by this world, desperate just to survive, to the point that he would permanently mutilate himself just to lessen the chance of something bad happening on accident."
Daarka 3/20/2023 10:34 PM
She nodded slowly, shifting to lean against the counter next to him. "... I don't think that's an unfair observation," she murmured thoughtfully. "... Gosh, where do I even begin..." Drawing in a deep breath, her gaze wandered the room as she tried to rewind the last hour or so and go through the mental notes she had been taking. "... I don't know what his baseline is. If what we saw tonight included it, then I feel reasonably confident of my judgment of him--but since this has been our only encounter, there's a possibility the entire thing was an act. If it was... it was a really good one. Something like that, only time will tell. But... assuming we saw the real him tonight... I'm inclined to agree with you. He gave me the impression of how you might have turned out if you never had a rebellious streak, and instead just buckled under the pain of life. If the coping mechanism had been to surrender and submit in an effort for it to be over faster, or to avoid conflict altogether. That much, at least, I can relate to. And if that's the kind of person Ludin is, it doesn't surprise me that he holds himself with so much cowardice and speaks with so much shame. He probably wishes he was prouder of the man he presented to his son. But he did come here at all, and I agree that does carry significance." She slowly ran her hand through her hair as she continued to work through her thoughts. "... Something that occurred to me early on was the timeline of everything. So we're fairly positive he has ties to the Blackswords, from up near Laracus. The mission you and I went on, we didn't... stop in any towns, really. The only person we encountered that wasn't Dr. Stein or his brother was that traveling merchant whose companions had all been eaten by mimics, and we sent him on his way and he looked scared to death and eager to head south. But we did kill two Blacksword lycans. I don't know what rumors could have been floating around about our presence in the Neck; we didn't encounter anyone beyond that. I think some sort of Blacksword presence became aware of those we had slain, and watched us enough to at least have a general description of us. Whether Ludin was one of those people, or whether he just heard about it through them later, I think that's more likely how he knew. Which is only noteworthy in that it proves he has the capacity to lie about details that could be problematic for him to include, as this was before you brought up the Blackswords by name. On that note... that mission was in October. The mission that went to Laracus was in December. It's now March. If we're to believe what he said at face value... it's taken him over three months to do nothing but travel from Laracus to Fielbarry." A beat. "Granted, he's so squirrely that I'm willing to excuse some of the extra time as him wringing his hands and waffling on it all. But what he told us was basically that once he knew where to look, he followed their trail back. He said he was able to track them back to Fielbarry. That would have had to take place freshly on their departure from the north for it to be possible, since he can't exactly follow a scent trail if he's not a werewolf. So... if we're to believe him at face value again, that means he's... been in this area for three months? Just hemming and hawing about whether he has the guts to approach you? Which... frankly, might be plausible, given his disposition. But it also opens up the possibility that there are things in that stretch of time he specifically did not talk about, or something else going on--or it was just another full lie."
Dakota 3/20/2023 11:13 PM
His brow furrowed, and he frowned deeply as he thought about it, his arms tightening where they were wrapped around himself.
