And so his tail wrapped around the accursed thing, and he carried it along as he went home. The dogs were gone. He didn't know where. Didn't... didn't have the capacity to care. Gummy would be gone, too, without Skena to sustain him. Night had passed, and dawn had risen by the time he was finished. Skena's body had been washed and prepared the best he knew how, her corpse laid out in front of the altar to Anubis. He'd found Gummy and had prepared him in a similar fashion, setting his unmoving body beside her head. No tears had been shed... He was beyond them. Shut down and withdrawn to a place without feeling, where nothing hurt. When sleep finally took him, he was curled up on the floor next to Skena's corpse, caked with grime and dried blood and viscera.
Daarka 7/12/2023 11:38 PM
Cold. But welcomed cold. He opened his eyes to find himself standing on a now rather familiar mountaintop, dusted in a layer of snow. The aurora borealis silently painting elaborate waves through the densely-starred sky above. The gentle, chilled wind tousled his hair slightly, and he stood for a moment and soaked it in, numb though he was. After a while he turned his head, feeling a presence more than hearing it. The Cautican god of death looked rather strange with this backdrop--but Kaleva had never seen Him so clearly. It was no golden shimmer outline this time. It was a man with the head of a dark jackal, standing tall--but at a mortal's height. He looked back at Kaleva with eyes mirroring the tiefling's aurora-teal color, though He did not break the silence. There was a quiet, gentle expectation to that quiet. An invitation, perhaps, for Kaleva to speak as he chose.
Dakota 7/12/2023 11:48 PM
The aurora did not fill him with the same wonder and comfort it would have otherwise. The spectacle was passively noted, and then discarded. When he noticed Anubis, he took a moment to take in His appearance. But he could not find the usual awe or reverence he usually felt when he looked upon Him. Nor could he find a single word to speak to the God who had taken him in. The cold felt particularly sharp on the tears that wet his face. But his expression was empty and glazed. He had... no desire left to live. None. There was no point in it. No joy he could think he would ever feel again. There wasn't even an afterlife to look forward to that would have Skena in it.
Daarka 7/12/2023 11:55 PM
Despite saying nothing, it was like the god heard what his heart was grappling with. He drew in a deep sigh, letting it out again slowly as His gaze wandered to look across the sky's lights. ... Faith is a fickle thing, at times. But you are not forsaken, my son. His words, deep and velvety, filled the air between them, as His gaze turned back to the tiefling. There is yet work to be done. A dark hand extended towards Kaleva in invitation, palm-up. You may not have faith in me in this moment. But you will, Kaleva.
Dakota 7/13/2023 12:01 AM
Kaleva looked at his extended hand, and reached out to place his own in it. He couldn't bring the words from his throat, mute as he had become, but the thoughts spoke in the way that dreams allowed, his intention reflected. It wasn't about faith. He didn't stop believing in Anubis, or having faith in Him. He just... had no capacity to find the will to live. Or to care what afterlife he wound up in, or what happened to him at all. But if Anubis had a task for him, he would do as He bade him. He owed Him that much.
Daarka 7/13/2023 12:11 AM
Fingers closed around Kaleva's hand, and with a gentle strength, the tiefling was drawn all the way into the god's arms, which enveloped him in the kind of security and comfort that put mortal hugs to shame. With the slender muzzle gently pressed atop the side of Kaleva's head, he could feel His voice rumble from His chest and directly into Kaleva's bones. True faith is blind, son of mine. But I will offer you a guiding star. His scent was earthy and rich in the most regal, yet comforting way. Scents that did not have names, nothing Kaleva had ever encountered on the material plane. As He continued to speak, even His breath was similarly captivating, a soft, warm gust down the side of his hair. A day of despair. That is all that can be taken from you. His body shifted, a hand sliding under Kaleva's to turn the tiefling's hand palm-up. And there, sitting in the center of his palm, was a fist-sized hourglass, its upper half filled with black sand that looked to have only begun to fall. Nothing more. (edited)
Dakota 7/13/2023 12:21 AM
He sank into the embrace, felt the rumble of His voice. The scent of His body, the desert warmth of His breath. Kaleva exhaled a shuddering sigh, his vision blurred with tears. He looked to his palm, the hourglass now sitting there. He didn't understand what Anubis meant. Or what He wanted. Nor did he have the capacity to try to figure it out.
Daarka 7/13/2023 12:26 AM
Anubis kept him in His embrace. In a sense, it was almost like comfortably falling asleep in that gentle, strong semblance of peace, as the dream gently, gently ebbed. When Kaleva opened his eyes again, they did not look out upon the northern lights. Merely up at the ceiling of their cottage's dining room. To his right lay the corpse of his soulmate. To his left, a small hourglass with black sand falling. On his chest, the small weight of a loafing minion.
Dakota 7/13/2023 11:11 AM
Kaleva's gaze settled on the minion on his chest, and he had the vague thought of 'I thought I mummified you.' Anubis' doing, no doubt. He sat up slowly, a hand beneath Gummy's bottom to keep him from sliding off, and stared at the hourglass. Twenty-four hours. To... What? To grieve? To prepare for the task Anubis had for him? To set things in order? The dogs were still gone. No... Wait. The huskies were gone. Atreyu was standing in the doorway, staring in with his head low and his tail tucked, his pumpkin orange eyes locked on the wrapped and shrouded body of Skena's corpse. Distantly, Kaleva found himself a little confused by Atreyu's behavior. But when he moved to stand up, Atreyu jerked back and snapped his attention to Kaleva, body crouched in preparation to run. And it clicked. Just a couple nights ago, he'd attacked Skena. Atreyu had intervened, terrified, but protective of her. And now she was dead, and he, covered in blood. He opened his mouth, tried to explain, but the words lodged in his throat like a physical barrier. He stepped forward again, a hand reached out, and Atreyu turned and bolted... And Kaleva could only watch him go hollowly.
Daarka 7/13/2023 11:16 AM
Gummy stirred as Kaleva roused, opening eyes to squint at him. But he stayed comfortably curled against his chest, a small but pleasant weight. An eye turned to watch the interaction with Atreyu, but whatever strange little thoughts may or may not have been passing through his little semblance of a mind remained unclear. In the silence that followed, he gave a single, crunchy croak of a meow. His head lifted to butt into the underside of Kaleva's chin, the end of his long, prehensile tail curling around his wrist as a dry purr softly rattled from the little body.
Dakota 7/13/2023 12:30 PM
Over the next few hours he found himself doing mindless tasks he barely even remembered. He put away the tools that had been left out. The lumber that had been cut. Opened the door to the fish house where dried fish hung, out of reach of most scavengers, but Atreyu would be able to access it. He put away or tossed out any food that would perish if left unattended for more than a week. He didn't know what was in store, but... He didn't really expect to come back. It finally reached a point where the only thing left to do was to bury Skena. He'd put Gummy around his shoulders, picking up Skena and a shovel and taking her out to the field of wildflowers where her bee hives were set up. In the shade of a lone oak tree he set her shrouded body down and began to dig. He was attracting as many flies as Skena's body at this point, caked in sweat, grime, and dried blood as he was.
Daarka 7/13/2023 12:38 PM
Gummy stayed snugly around his shoulders the whole time, purring a quiet rattle in his ears that mingled with the hum of the bees around them. He was about done with the hole when his keen ears would pick up the faint sound of an approach. A small body, running through the long grasses and wildflowers... before coming to a halt a distance away. The little violet tiefling was petite, but still too tall to have been Skena. Bright cyan eyes stared, wide, down at the wrapped body. The hole being dug. The look on Kaleva's face. Slower than she had initially approached, Ingrid tentatively walked forward again, looking ready to stop on a dime if she was driven back. "... Kaleva... Love..." she managed haltingly after a few long moments, "... What happened?"
Dakota 7/13/2023 3:57 PM
Kaleva paused in his digging, panting slightly from exertion, one ear twitching in Ingrid's direction. When he looked up at her mutely, it was with that same hollow emptiness she hadn't seen since he was in prison. The dull hue of his blue-green eyes, haunted, that spoke what his voice could not. Skena was dead, and he had lost the capacity for speech. He could only look at her with that lifeless, hopeless stare, as if from the deepest depths of a pit he had no hope of getting out of.
Daarka 7/13/2023 4:19 PM
Ingrid's hand hovered over her mouth, and she just... stared. So much of her life was spent in the role of a lazy stoner slut who took nothing at all seriously. Kaleva and Arsast knew there was a layer beneath that, though. Knew that she was perfectly capable of taking things seriously. And some things were so stone-cold serious, that it would be insane to not see them as such. Kaleva being betrayed by his first lover, landing him in prison where he rotted and was subjected to horrible mistreatment, while the lover who put him there told everyone a horrible lie about the circumstances to paint herself a sympathetic victim in it all... that was a very good thing to take seriously. Ingrid had wanted that to be the only thing she'd ever have to take seriously. But there was the linen-wrapped form of a little body. There was a hole in the ground. There was that look on his face that she didn't want to ever see again because of the cold way it turned her stomach. And she knew there were no words when his eyes were that dull. When his face was that empty. She hated that circumstances had brought them to this point, but... she had a role in it that she at least carried experience with. He didn't need to say anything. "... Beloved..." It was so hard for her to find words. What could you possibly say? I'm sorry for your loss? Something internally scoffed at the half-assed proposition of such a sentiment. How incredibly hollow. How fucking meaningless that would be to offer him. Words wouldn't comfort him. She could tell just by looking at him. Potentially nothing could comfort him. But she made a decision after a horrible moment of silence that she was at least going to be fucking helpful, and not waste her breath on thoughts and prayers. Stepping forward, she steadily closed the distance between them, looking over the dirt and dried gore covering him. She didn't know whose blood it was (she'd never really learned of the unique properties of Skena's that would have informed her if it had belonged to the girl). A part of her wondered if Kaleva had... done this. Like Atreyu had, it was hard not to guess at that upon seeing what was laid before her. But she approached him with no manner of caution. He had no life left in him; he wasn't a danger. Except, possibly, to himself. Her hand weaved a graceful gesture through the air, and over a few seconds of similar movement, the layer of filth was thoroughly dissolved from his skin. One tiny iota of the misery relieved. A drop in the ocean. "... Kaleva... sweetheart... before ye put her in the ground..." she murmured slowly, her words impossibly gentle, "... Magic is capable of a great many things. Some of it is beyond me personally, but there are many avenues tae pursue. 'Specially in such a town as this one. I donnae... ken what ye already been through, but... would you like tae talk options? Beloved, there're always options."
Dakota 7/13/2023 4:25 PM
He barely seemed to register that the gore had been removed from him, but he did seem to register her words, even if his pupilless gaze was focused somewhere beyond her. He turned his gaze to the sword that lay in the grass nearby - he'd taken it with, he wouldn't let it leave his sight, didn't trust that someone wouldn't try to reclaim it. It was still stained with Skena's blood, and Ingrid would be familiar enough with Kaleva's dual scimitars to know it was not one of his.
Daarka 7/13/2023 4:36 PM
She followed his gaze. It took her a second to understand his implications, before she glanced back to him a moment, then walked over to the sword. Her movements remained slow and steady, easy to stop at any point if he tried to halt her actions--but without an intervention, she would stoop down to delicately pick it up, looking at the blood over it. Immediately noticing the difference between that, and the blood that had coated Kaleva; no... he hadn't killed her. He'd killed someone. Presumably this blade's owner. She turned it over it her hands, frowning at it a moment. Then she murmured a soft word in another language, tapping her perfectly manicured nails down the flat of the blade in a rapid, short series of little ticking sounds. In response, small but shimmery magic flashed across the weapon--and Ingrid sucked in a breath, eyes widening slightly. She stared at the sword for a long moment. Before unceremoniously dropping it onto the dirt again, her face blank with shock as she processed what she had divined. It took her a few seconds, before she drew in a deep breath, and released a long sigh, looking back to Kaleva with understanding. But not matching his hopelessness. "... That is... vile. It... certainly eliminates some of ye options... but not all of them. There is magic in this world that can undo such things. Just..." Her brows knit, fingers slowly running through her dreadlocks as she thought. "... High magic. Far beyond me. Beyond most. But Ah ken it exists. There are options, beloved," she insisted again, looking to him gently. "And... ye have me unwaverin' an' eternal assistance in pursuin' any of 'em. Ye..." A hand lifted to loosely gesture to where the corpse of his soulmate lay, before her hand flopped down to her side again, "... Ye cannae live like this. We'll fix it. Aight? I... donnae ken exactly how, but we gonna fix it, Kaleva."
Dakota 7/13/2023 4:48 PM
...Maybe that was the task Anubis had for him. To find this high magic, this means of bringing Skena back. He... wanted to hope. But he was afraid to. Afraid to feel hope, to feel like there was a chance, because if it turned out there wasn't, or that he failed, or that it just wasn't possible... He couldn't... Couldn't deal with that again. Couldn't deal with the loss all over again. But if it was possible... What... was he supposed to do with Skena's body in the interim? The canopic jars that housed her organs sat next to her body. Would he have to... put them back in her? Sew them back into place? He stood in the pit he'd dug, and stared helplessly at the shrouded bundle.
Daarka 7/13/2023 4:53 PM
Ingrid wasn't too dense to figure out what he was grappling with as she watched him look around helplessly. "... That's the pickle, innit," she sighed. "... The particular spell isnae in me own repertoire--but there's much easier magic tae preserve such things. Not only keeps 'em from gettin' gross, but it stops a certain clock. Resurrection-type spells are easier tae do the less time has passed from the death--an' I donnae even ken if we'll ultimately end up on that breed'a magic. But if we do... the preservation magic will stop that clock. An' it can keep bein' cast on 'er until we have a solution. It could take us a year, but she'll have still only been like this, far as the magic's concerned, up tae this point. Makes sense, hopefully? If ye personally donnae know any other folks what might be able tae do that--usually the more healing-oriented spellcasters--I can go shake some people down tae see who might be able tae help with that as soon as possible."
Dakota 7/13/2023 5:04 PM
...Cassiana was a healer-oriented spellcaster, if he remembered correctly. Though part of him was... terrified to go over there. Because of Margret and Stefan in particular. He could envision their tears and their grief all too easily, how they'd try to comfort him... And he... couldn't handle that. Anubis was one thing. But he was afraid of their grief. Afraid of their efforts at comfort and consolation. ...Maybe he could bring Ingrid there and direct her to Cassiana's, have her bring Cassiana to him alone. He set aside the shovel and climbed up out of the hole, moving to Skena's body to gather the canopic jars and tuck them against her chest before gathering her up and starting to make his way there, his tail curling around the sword to drag it along behind him. The walk was a lot longer without Atreyu, but he had little hope of seeing the hound again. He had no idea what had happened to the huskies... But they were like siblings to Atreyu. Wherever they were, he was sure the hound was seeing to their well-being. As they neared the pair of cottages and the stable, Kaleva looked to Ingrid, then to the house that Cassiana and Nils shared. He made a pointed little motion of his head, and then retreated a ways away.
Daarka 7/13/2023 5:09 PM
Ingrid was timelessly patient as he sorted through things, and when he gathered up what was left of Skena, she followed after him. She hadn't been to this part of the forest before. A part of her inevitably found the little Holbrekkan cottages to be charming as shit. The rest of her was too distracted with the nature of her visit. She returned Kaleva's gaze, doing her best to decipher his meaning. "... I take it ye know a guy? An' they in there. Aight. Sit tight, love." Leaving him in the trees, she headed towards the cottage he had indicated her towards. Kaleva was a wallflower in general, and borderline shut down at the moment; she was happy to supplement the words and charisma he couldn't manage. Knocking on the door, her tail idly swirled behind her with its excessive length in shifting loops--but the usual shitkid whimsy was absent from her face. Not that these residents even knew her in the first place.
Dakota 7/13/2023 5:13 PM
"One second!" Heavy footsteps eventually came to the door, and the heavy wooden thing opened to reveal a 100% pure tiefling-flavored Holbrekkan thirst trap of a man, his pale blue skin muscular and dusted with coppery hair, the long copper hair on his head pulled back into a ponytail and accented with beads and braids. Dressed in a simple white tunic and pants, a belt knotted around his middle, his kinked tail quirked in curiosity and he tilted his head and smiled at Ingrid. "Oh, hello. Don't believe I've seen you around before - are you looking for someone?"
Daarka 7/13/2023 5:19 PM
Normally, Ingrid would have made some horribly forward and brazen comment towards the man now in front of her; he was undoubtedly her type. It spoke volumes that the thought didn't even cross her mind at present. Her eyes gave a faint squint, but there wasn't quite a smile on her lips. "No--Ye donnae ken me. Me name's Ingrid. I'm an old friend of Kaleva's." Her words were soft. Muted. "He indicated tae me someone here may know how tae cast gentle repose." There was a shifting from behind Nils, accompanied a moment later by the muffled tap of a staff as his wife turned a (mutedly) concerned gaze towards the stranger at the door. "... Is everything alright...?" She knew even as she asked it that it was a stupid question. "No, love. Very much nae alright," Ingrid replied, calm, but very well composed. "But we're workin' tae rectify it. First thing in priority is easin' the penalty of passin' time, aye?" (edited)
Dakota 7/13/2023 5:23 PM
The welcoming smile slid off Nils' face as he began to work out what was going on, and a kind of slow, muted horror began to set in. He was... he was sure that Skena would have had the capacity to cast that particular spell, but that would mean... "Take us to them, please," he whispered, one hand at Cass' back.
Daarka 7/13/2023 5:24 PM
Cass immediately planted her good hand on Nils' arm, looking pointedly at him. "Darling... you are not obligated to accompany me," she said softly. She... didn't know what such a situation would do to him.
Dakota 7/13/2023 5:25 PM
"I..." Nils hesitated, looking to Cass. But... she was right. Even though Skena and Kaleva were friends and he felt like he should be there, it was also... It might hit too close to home. And he didn't want to make it about him if he accidentally wound up triggered. "...Yeah. I'll... Should I go tell Ma and Dad?"
Daarka 7/13/2023 5:29 PM
"... That is up to you, love," Cass replied softly. "If you need their support, then yes. I'll do what I can on my own; I would only want you beside me if it was not to your detriment." Her grip on his arm gave a small, gentle squeeze. "If you are not sure, then stay safe."
Dakota 7/13/2023 9:03 PM
The big, burly tiefling's lower lip wobbled, and he gave a little nod and leaned in to kiss Cassiana's cheek, giving her arm a squeeze. Ingrid was given one last misty-eyed look, and then, quietly distressed, he went and retreated back into the house. A ways away, Kaleva went to sit down and wait for Ingrid to return with Cass, cradling the shrouded bundle in his arms and rocking slowly over it, his cheek atop the covered head.
Daarka 7/13/2023 9:21 PM
The two very starkly different women returned to where Kaleva was waiting not long after, and though Cassiana was not an expressive individual, her face softened mutedly in compassion at the sight. Hobbling over, she slowly leaned down to merely brush fingertips over the linen-wrapped head, withdrawing again afterwards. From her touch, wisps of grey smoke slithered across the body's exterior, then seemed to soak in to the body beneath. "... Ten days, my friend. That will last ten days," she murmured with reverent quietness. "If you do not have a remedy in ten days, you find me again, and I will repeat the magic. However many times it is necessary." Her brows knit ever so faintly, head tilting slightly to the side. "... As long as this tragedy is not more than a handful of days old, I can--" She paused as Ingrid's hand found her shoulder, and she glanced over to see the teifling shaking her head. "... Foul magic went on here. The typical resurrections... I could be wrong, but I donnae think they'd do the trick. I think... at this point... we lookin' for some manner of wish." "... Ah." Cass quieted. "... Then... do let us know if there is... anything we can do to assist that effort. Nils and I are not... of particularly high arcane capacity... and my own abilities are rather mysterious in nature. But if there is something we can assist with, we will..." A pause. "... How did this... come to happen?" Ingrid didn't let the silence put pressure on Kaleva to answer himself. "Nae entirely sure. What does it matter?" She asked smoothly, her words gentle, yet bearing a sort of firmness that was ready to guard Kaleva from an interrogation if one was brewing. But Cassiana, of course, had no such intentions. "If there is mystery to it... I have some things that may assist." She looked back to Kaleva, her gaze soft. "But not without informed consent. I can display the last seconds of life, if there is uncertainty in how things transpired--but if it is not a mystery worth solving, bearing witness to such a thing may be inhumane. I am... also able to speak to the memories lingering in the physical vessel--though I cannot communicate with her true person. Her soul. If there is needed information that she would have had in life, I can pose questions to the echoes of those memories. But again... to witness such a thing may be unbearable. I would not advise it if it is not necessary."
Dakota 7/13/2023 9:34 PM
There was a mystery to it... But he wasn't sure exactly if Skena would have the answers. Still, it might... He wanted to know. He wanted to know... why. Ludin hadn't even fought back, really, beyond reflexive defensive motions. But he couldn't understand why he'd even... He lifted his gaze to Cassiana, and nodded slowly, granting her permission to look into Skena's last moments and see what happened.
Daarka 7/13/2023 9:41 PM
Cass met his gaze, though she did not yet move to oblige him. "... I have used this to watch my own death. It can only portray the death of an individual once; there is no recasting it to see it again later." A pause. "It will perfectly show her. It does not display any other creatures or items or scenery. If your reason for wanting it is a question that would not be solved with those constraints... it may not be worth having the images in your mind." Another pause. "... But if such a display would answer your questions... it would likely be kinder to bear witness to than hearing the body speak in death to answer questions more elaborately." (edited)
Dakota 7/13/2023 10:08 PM
As she described what he would actually see, he balked. In that case, no, it didn't sound like his questions would be answered and would just... It was bad enough seeing what he did. He didn't have the strength to witness it if it wouldn't hold answers. But if she could get answers out of Ludin, then... He shuddered, pulling Skena's body a little tighter, and shifted to his feet once more. Turning a quietly pleading look to Cassiana, he made a small motion of his head for her to follow, and began to back away a bit. If she was willing to come, he'd take her to the other body.
Daarka 7/13/2023 10:12 PM
She certainly didn't mind the lack of social skills. She nodded patiently, glad she had taken the effort to explain her magic before doing it, and setting off to hobble along after him. As she set off, she expected it would be more than a five minute road trip, so she reached back out to her husband's mind. 'I'm needed a bit offsite. I don't expect to be gone long, but I will reach out again if it looks that way. Drink some tea. I'll be home soon.'
Dakota 7/13/2023 10:17 PM
'Okay. Love you,' Nils replied back softly. Between Kaleva's burden and Cassiana's handicap, it was a bit slow going, but Kaleva eventually guided both women to the ravaged remains of Ludin's body. Insects were already starting to feast on the corpse, and a few crows cawed and scattered as they approached, but on the whole the body was still somewhat recognizable as a dark-skinned tiefling with severed and cauterized horns, lacking any sort of tail.
Daarka 7/13/2023 10:22 PM
It took her a moment. Then the recognition set in. Cass' steps halted as she stared at the man a long moment. With a bit of effort, she tore her gaze away to look questioningly towards Kaleva. "... Forgive me, I... I understand you are not having an easy time communicating. But... who is this man to you?" She asked softly, sparing a glance at Ingrid in case she knew--but the tiefling clearly was seeing this for the first time herself, so Cass returned her gaze to Kaleva. "... This is the man who led us to the Blackswords when our group traveled to Laracus."
Dakota 7/13/2023 10:29 PM
That information didn't seem like it surprised Kaleva at all. He swallowed and licked his lips, trying to... trying to figure out how to communicate... Even mouthing the word felt foul and his throat closed up around any sort of sound, but he mouthed the word 'father' and then looked away, jaw clenched and eyes tight.
Daarka 7/13/2023 10:43 PM
Both Cass and Ingrid watched his lips closely, and both more or less gleaned the correct word after a moment. Ingrid took a deep breath, closing her eyes a moment, before simply reaching to place her hand on the back of Kaleva's shoulder. Cass was quiet for a contemplative moment, taking that in. "... Strange." A beat passed, before she decided to continue. "... He introduced himself as Nowhere. We came across him on the edge of town; we had been told to look for him, and recognized him by chance. He was... apprehensive. Wary. We feigned an interest in joining the Blackswords. He..." A pause. "... To tell you the truth, Kaleva... he looked horribly reluctant. He gave us... so many opportunities to turn back. All but told us to stay away. We persisted. So he led us up the mountain, to the den where the Blackswords seemingly resided." She didn't know if it eased the sense of betrayal to hear of his reluctance. To know he was not the same enthusiastic-seeming zealot as the rest. Or perhaps there were clues in her description that she couldn't foresee. "... The man we took for the leader of the Blackswords was a shifter. He introduced himself as Ivolde. Nowhere wouldn't look him in the eye. Ivolde spoke to him... rather scathingly. Almost taunting him at times. Nowhere wilted under his words, like he hated being there. Ivolde spoke to us, ultimately leading us down into a cavern where a pegasus was trapped. Nowhere did not follow us. Ivolde tried to call our bluff, prompted Niamh to slay the pegasus to prove our intent. She instead freed the beast. In the commotion, we fled. Nowhere was not in the den on our exit, and we did not see him at any point thereafter. I... do not know if this information has any meaning to you," she admitted gently. Her gaze shifted back to the gruesome remains on the ground. "... If I speak to the echoes of his life, I can ask five questions. He will only know what he knew in life, and it will not be true communication with the man himself. Only an echo of him." She looked back to Kaleva with a gentle concern. "I will not know what to ask. Would it help you to write down your thoughts?"
Dakota 7/14/2023 7:05 AM
Kaleva looked at Cassiana as she explained her experience with the corpse on the ground, and that hollow and empty look became pinched, his jaw clenching and the hair at his nape bristling. Again it seemed as though the information she gave was no surprise to him... He seemed familiar enough with Ludin to have known about his general demeanor. He knelt to set Skena down, reaching for a nearby stick to scratch in the dirt, 'W H Y.' Underlined. Then underlined again, the motions abrupt and angry. There were five questions, but that's the only question that he had.
Daarka 7/14/2023 11:12 AM
Cass looked over the word in the dirt, giving a single, quiet nod, and hobbling forward a few steps. "... Unlike the other magic, I will be able to speak to his memories in this way again--but only once every ten days. So long as a mouth remains with which it can answer me." With a bit of stiffness and difficulty, but also familiarity with the struggle, the elf carefully began lowering herself to the ground beside the body, not seeming worried about if her dress would become dirtied in the gore. She settled in, glancing over to Kaleva again. "... If his response provokes more questions, we will have ten minutes in total during which the remaining questions can be utilized." Ingrid stirred at that, a flick of her wrist summoning a pretty tome into her hand; a flick of her other wrist produced an iridescent quill. "Here, love. If ye need tae write anythin' further, I'll make it easy on ye," she offered gently, extending both to him in offering now that his hands were free of their previous burdens. If he opened the tome, he would see--briefly--glimpses of semi-coherent notes, runes, and arcane scribblings... but those markings melted away on whatever page he opened, leaving it blank and useable for him. Similarly, though she had provided no source of ink, the quill would write smoothly and without seeming to need any, leaving rich black ink on the page. Cass dipped her head slightly in appreciation for the further assistance on that front. "... You are welcome to linger if you wish to witness this personally. But if not, I would take your leave now--and I will do my best to utilize the remaining questions as efficiently as possible between the intuition of myself and your friend here--" "Ingrid." "Ingrid, yes."
Dakota 7/14/2023 11:18 AM
Kaleva took the book and quill in hand, his tufted tail flicking slightly, just once, before settling limp again. He gave a curt nod to Cassiana. He was staying.
Daarka 7/14/2023 11:30 AM
"Very well." She turned her attention squarely onto the corpse, looking over his wounds a moment in... what almost felt like a silent, somber reverence. It seemed Nowhere had murdered Skena. She, too, would be interested to know why. She shifted to lie her staff down on the ground beside her, her good hand then moving to grasp a beetle crawling across Ludin's face and toss it aside. Then she rested her palm against his cheek, her spectral hand settling on the opposite side to ever so softly cradle his bloodied face. Eyes that had been a rich, bright icy blue in life were now dull and glazed over, closer to the color of Cassiana's in the end. He had looked so pitiful in life, and it was even more so in death. He looked oddly small, frail, and... sad. His face was slack and expressionless, but there was a sadness drenched over him nonetheless. A tragic life, a tragic death. Cassiana--Eidunn--leaned forward slightly, her eyes lidding as she drew in a deep breath, and then released a long, slow exhale. The breath that poured from her lips came in the form of more of that grey smoke, which spilled through the air, swirling in an elegant, wisping tendril that snaked into Nowhere's nose and mouth, and a keen eye would even see the battered remains of his chest begin to lift, expanding for likely the last time with a breath that wasn't even his own. As the smoke bled into the corpse in its entirety, a few seconds of silence stretched out. And then, ever so softly, the elf murmured, "... Nowhere... Why did you kill Skena?" The head in her hands shifted ever so slightly. As if muscles wanted to turn it to face her, but stiffness, weakness, and brokenness made the movement incomplete. With a similar stiffness, the lips moved--ineffectively at first, but then, in a hoarse and hollow whisper... "... I... don't... know..." With the words, small bits of that smoke escaped again, dissipating into the air. A finite resource, now partially depleted. "... I'm... so... sorry..."
Dakota 7/14/2023 11:37 AM
Kaleva's tail whipped back and forth at the answer, increasingly agitated, hatred and distress on his features. He wrote in the book and turned it to Cassiana. 'What does he remember?'
Daarka 7/14/2023 11:43 AM
Cass glanced over to the book, dipped her chin slightly, and then turned back to the corpse. "What do you remember happened before you killed her?" "... Heard... her... calling..." the head wheezed hoarsely, only the faintest echo of a memory of emotion to the words. "Came... to... her... She... greeted me... and... then... looked... above... my... head... And I... saw... Ivolde's... sword... in... her..."
Dakota 7/14/2023 12:01 PM
He stilled at that, and closed his eyes. So, it hadn't been a conscious choice in Ludin's part. He... remembered the way it felt when he saw Ludin over Skena's body. Hadn't... questioned it. Hadn't had the ability to question it. But he'd felt the beast rise up, felt the... the evil in it. He remained motionless as he absorbed the information. Reflected on the stupid, simple tragedy of Ludin's entire fucking existence. Because Ludin was as far from antagonistic as one got. He was just a puppet in this. And he remembered the resignation in his terrified gaze. Dragging in a sharp breath, he opened his eyes and wrote once more in the book. 'Ask him if he wants the chance to make things right.'
Daarka 7/14/2023 12:09 PM
Ingrid and Cassiana had none of the context that raced through Kaleva's mind, and both eyed him with different flavors of rapt attention. Cass looked over the written words, then again back to the glassy eyes that very nearly matched her own. She took a deep breath, thinking a moment. She... remembered how squirrely Nowhere had been. Ingrid had never met him, but Cassiana had been up close and personal, trying to ascertain his character for a moderately extended period. She saw the way he crumpled so effortlessly under Ivolde's biting words hurled at him. The way, even in death, the echo of his life could only apologize at what he'd done. She did not repeat Kaleva's question verbatim. "... If there were the chance for you to truly make things right... to make a difference, and heal what you have hurt... If you did have the power to affect change... would you wish to make that effort?" For the first time, a few muscles twitched on the corpse's face. Not a complete expression, not true emoting--but the faintest attempt of his brows to knit. "... That... is... why... I... came... at all..." came the words, almost faint enough to miss.
Dakota 7/14/2023 12:26 PM
Kaleva let out a short exhale, closing the book and handing it and the quill back to Ingrid. He held up a hand to motion for them to wait there, and went to gather up Skena's body and head back home. There were two other questions, but he had heard what he needed. And he knew Skena kept a couple of diamonds around for resurrection purposes. Her corpse wasn't going to deteriorate further for a while, but it was still something that would attract flies. The shroud he'd wrapped her in had protected her so far, but he didn't know how long he'd be gone. He tucked her body away in her room off the kitchen, covering it as best he could and shutting the door tight. He took a moment to don his armor and his swords, and retrieve the hourglass Anubis had given him, along with the diamond that would be needed to revive Ludin. When he returned, he opened his hand and held the diamond out to Cassiana.
Daarka 7/14/2023 12:35 PM
Throughout this process, Gummy stayed on his shoulders. When he moved to don his armor, the minion shifted minutely, but rather stubbornly endeavored to stay put. As Kaleva picked up the hourglass, he'd notice about a quarter, perhaps a little more, of the sand had now fallen to the bottom. He would also notice as he held it, that regardless of the angle he held it at, the sand always fell straight to the bottom, as if gravity within the little vessel was warped to always allow it to move as intended. Cassiana looked up as he returned, her gaze falling to the diamond he offered her, and her expression softening slightly. She reached out to accept the little stone, looking it over a moment. This was more than something that could be fixed with revivify. He had been here at least a day, rotting, being eaten by wildlife. And his death had been... well. Nearly comparable to her own in terms of the destruction wrought. Her fingers closed around the diamond. "... I will do my best. But if I succeed, he will need time to recover," she murmured gently. She gestured with her incorporeal hand, beckoning Kaleva closer. "Come. I will need all of your help. Time has passed since his soul has departed, and so there is more to be done to try to bring it back."
Dakota 7/14/2023 12:39 PM
Kaleva gave a curt nod, and then reached up to offer the hourglass to Gummy to hold on to for now. Assuming the minion vored it, he then turned his attention to Cassiana, awaiting instructions.
Daarka 7/14/2023 1:27 PM
Gummy was a simple man. And this particular item... yes. Yes, something told him Skena would have wanted it. And so his grubby little paws closed around it, and it got a good sniffing all over--and then down his throat it went. Cassiana beckoned him closer still, gesturing for him to sit beside her around the corpse. Ingrid hesitated only a moment, but when Cass glanced at her to do the same, she stepped forward as well, willing to do anything she could as long as she could confirm she was welcome. The tiefling knelt in the iron-stained grass on the opposite side of the body, watching the elf across from her silently. Cass reached out to hold the diamond in her hand, her fist placed over where Ludin's heart was. She closed her eyes and drew in a deep breath, even as smoke began to silently bleed from her form, billowing up into the air around them. "I will reach out to wherever his soul has gone, and my magic will give it at avenue through which it has a hope of returning," she explained, her words smooth and stony as the changes to her form consumed her. "But his spirit must choose to return. Between the three of us... we must convince it to do so, by any means necessary." Her fist opened--but no diamond fell out. Only more streams of smoke, which were rapidly cloaking their surroundings in a grey haze. The smell was of burning charcoal and incense--but it did not abrade the lungs when it was breathed the way normal smoke would have. Instead, breathing it was a strange sensation, almost as if slipping into the effects of a drug; everything felt surreal. And perhaps a little more abstract than it had been before; a little more like a dream. And Cassiana looked far less like herself. The smoke all originated from her body, her eyes--pale, glassy blue before--now with a pupil that had dilated so much, it consumed all that had previously been her irises, and widened even further into the dull whites of her eyes. Beady black. Predatory, in a way that was jarring to those accustomed to her usual appearance. There was a deep and primal intensity in her features, and when she spoke, it was with a raking rasp to her voice, and a flat, cold lack of inflection. "You seem to have spent your life in flight, Nowhere. Flight is for prey--and so, too, have you fallen between the teeth of those who chased you. You have a rare chance, here, to live better. To find the chance to thrive amongst your survival. To not flee from that which chases you, but to stand your ground and face it down. May you learn, from your death, that flight only excites the predators at your heels; but life does not have to be a chase. Now is your chance to evolve." A hissing silence settled after her words, and she closed her eyes for a moment, before opening them again and looking to Ingrid, giving a pointed tip of her head. Ingrid regarded the corpse for a moment. What to say to a man you never knew? When her own voice came, it was not warped as Eidunn's was. It was its usual, silky, eloquent self, and it did what it did best: coax. "... I donnae know ye. Ye donnae know me. But I know ye son. An' I know the girl he loves." A beat. "An' I know he wanted to bring ye intae that love, too. Ye cannae be betrayed by someone ye didnae put trust in. His hurt right now is a reflection of the love he wanted tae give ye. That we here right now, doin' this crazy shite, tryin' tae drag ye ass back from wherever ye ended up--Kaleva did this. Kaleva wants ye here, among the livin'. Ye have one chance to truly make things better. An' if ye got a single damn thing in common with this son of ye's, Ah think ye capable of it. So put on ye big boy panties, an' come be here for the one who needs ye most; ye need tae leave this place better than ye found it, an' ye not done with that yet."
1:27 PM
Kaleva wasn't sure what the others were seeing. But he... could see Ludin. Space and time had distorted themselves long ago at this point, but he was looking at him, clear as day. Lying on his back, pinned to the burning ground by massive, vicious claws over him. Towering over him, a horrid monster of a wolf, mostly restrained in golden chains that held him in place--but with just enough allowance for the beast to have trapped Ludin under his grasp. Wide ears were rigidly held forward, and a tail would have been raised had the chains not stifled its movements. As Kaleva looked on, watched Ludin trapped there without even the will to try to free himself, the enormous beast's head lifted to lock eyes with Kaleva. Beady, black eyes. Predatory--but in a way that made Cassiana's look like those of a doormouse. In their centers burned a red-hot ember of a pupil; a tiny pinprick, but feeling like it lanced right through Kaleva. There was something goading there. A challenge. An invitation. Mockery. Hunger. The wolf's mouth was lodged open with a long sword that skewered down through the top of the muzzle and out the bottom, the jaw held permanently ajar. Never fully open, never fully closed. And from those wounds where the weapon pierced through its face, a deep, black blood oozed in a steady, never-ending drip, staining the sword's blade in that obsidian ichor, and splashing down to the desecrated ground around its prey.
Avrae BOT 7/14/2023 1:28 PM
Cassiana Hale makes a Survival check!
1d20 (2) + 8 = 10
1:28 PM
Ingrid makes a Persuasion check!
1d20 (9) + 10 = 19
Daarka 7/14/2023 1:29 PM
Cass' should actually be an 11. She has a +9, sheet must not be updated. Ohp. And Ingrid's would be a 21. She has a +12, I needed to update both of them. (edited)
Dakota 7/14/2023 1:46 PM
Kaleva's eyes widened, then narrowed into slits as the visage of Fenrir locked eyes with him. His lips pulled back from his teeth, and a gutteral snarl tore loose from his throat as his hackles bristled and raised up. Black fur spread across his form as his body shifted, stretched, and contorted into that of a wolf that looked nearly a miniature version of that which pinned down Ludin, with a tail that was nearly twice as long as a normal wolf's, and oversized ears. He moved forward and tried to brace himself over Ludin, to shoulder back the chained wolf, snapping at him and trying to pull Ludin free from his grip.

2d20kh1 (9, 18) + 4 = 22
Dakota 7/14/2023 2:14 PM

Avrae BOT 7/14/2023 2:47 PM
@Daarka Result: 1d20 (5) Total: 5
Daarka 7/14/2023 5:07 PM
As Kaleva thrust himself between his father and the demon pinning him, he found himself starkly dwarfed by the chained monster. It was larger than him, larger than Atreyu; perhaps more comparable, in size, to the stature of a dragon. But it was bound. And Kaleva had so little left to lose. Kaleva fixed his teeth around Ludin's shoulder--not like the last time he had done so. His bite now was to grip, not maim, as he hauled back on the man with all his strength, doing all he could to pry him away from the claws that trapped him like stakes in the heated soil around him. If he could just... get him out of Fenrir's reach, it was clear Fenrir couldn't pursue beyond those bounds. The beast was a powerful threat, but Tyr's sacrifice still meant something. And in this moment, it gave Kaleva and his father a quite literal chance in hell. Fenrir's head swung as if to snap back at the lycan beneath him--but that sword rendered his muzzle little more than a battering ram, and even that use was hindered with the chains snapping taut, stifling the full weight of the blow. It roughly shoved into Kaleva's flank like the kick of a massive horse--but those mitigating factors hamstringed the full potential of the blow, and Kaleva stayed on his feet. The snarl that rumbled from the demon was ungodly in every way. All-consuming. It seeped into Kaleva's ears. It trembled the air in a way that... very nearly sounded like cackling. The beast wasn't furious; he was manic. He reveled in this. And bound or not... he was winning this game of tug-of-war. Ludin had cried out when Kaleva's teeth sank into him, flinching as he had before. But in the chaos of snarling beasts, it... became clear that his son had not transcended the boundaries of life and death merely to rend him to pieces again. Perhaps some of the words that had been spoken in the ritual over his corpse even registered in his mind. Ludin began to struggle. No longer a helpless, dead weight, he frantically twisted his body to try to desperately thrash out--not from between Kaleva's teeth, but from between Fenrir's claws. One hand even blindly groped up behind his head, knotting his fingers in the wolf's scruff, trying to secure the lycan's grip on him. The demon's claws sank into his torso as it tried to slide free, bright red blood staining the tattered clothes Ludin had died in, the fluid sizzling and beginning to turn black as it met the stale, vile air around them. But one of Fenrir's enormous claws slipped off the protection of Ludin's ribs, and sank into the vulnerable softness of his midsection, delving deep into the meat and innards and looking like it would nearly run him through. Kaleva lived with three dogs. He had seen what happened to a toy being stretch between two of them, when the material in the middle began to give way. Ludin screamed in agony, his grip in Kaleva's fur trembling--but remaining. Sensing his advantage, Fenrir's claws began to flex back, straining against his bindings to try to drag the man back under him. Back under his control. Even if it tore him in half to do so. Everything was unpleasantly hot, the air sickeningly stagnant around them--but there was a sudden coldness at Kaleva's shoulder. A reflexive glance to the side caught the sight of a narrow figure--and for a moment, his breath caught in his throat. It was a pale woman, with pale hair, and eyes blacked out in their entirety, a look of cold ferocity on her face. In that fleeting second, it... could have been Skena. But then he realized why it was not. She looked far older, and he only glimpsed her from the side. It was only when she extended an arm that he realized who he was looking at; the half of her body not facing him was blue and necrotic, gaunt and withered, the eye on that side of her face glassy and white.
SPOILER
SPOILER
5:07 PM
Her clothes and long, wispy hair trailed behind her as she lunged forward, as if suspended through water. Her sickly blue hand reached forward with the sound of creaking bones, her appearance and rush forward happening in a mere fraction of a second. That hand lifted, aimed to land upon Fenrir's face, to do... gods knew what. Kaleva could only guess. But Fenrir seemed to know enough to take it as a serious threat. The demon jolted, snarled reflexively at the goddess, strained and thrashed back against its bindings in an effort to avoid her touch. And as it recoiled... its grip slipped. Kaleva sucked in a ragged gasp of breath, and his throat felt like he had been screaming for hours. His lungs cracked and ached as though he'd been breathing in soot and ash. His limbs trembled with exertion, sweat dampening every inch of skin. Skin... not fur. He was not transformed. He sat on the forest floor, Cassiana and Ingrid alongside him. And the body of his father between them all--also gasping and choking for breath. Ludin has never died before; his base resurrection DC was 10. Cassiana's contribution had a DC of 15. She rolled an 11. She failed. The resurrection DC increased to 11. Ingrid's contribution had a DC of 15. She rolled a 21. She succeeded. The resurrection DC decreased to 8. Kaleva's contribution had a DC of 20. He rolled a 23. He succeeded. The resurrection DC decreased to 5. The resurrection roll was a 5. The resurrection succeeds.
Dakota 7/14/2023 6:39 PM
Kaleva doubled over, coughing hoarsely, his eyes watering at the raw ache of his throat and lungs. It took him a minute to realize that the spell had succeeded, that Ludin had been brought back to life. He glanced around for a moment, located the sword he'd been dragging along with him, and curled his tufted tail around it securely once more, keeping himself between it and Ludin. He looked over the man with a grim set to his jaw and a new understanding of just how trapped his father had been, how little control over his own circumstances he must have had for untold ages. That was going to end, if he had anything to say about it.
Daarka 7/14/2023 7:15 PM
Cass' appearance had gone back to normal, the smoke around them mostly dissipated as she and Ingrid both jolted in response to the once-corpse between them now jerking with the agony of life. Ludin struggled to breathe for several excruciating seconds, potentially feeling the same way Kaleva did (the women present did not seem so afflicted). Or maybe it had to do with the state of his body. He did not... quite have open wounds. The magic seemed to have sealed them. Hopefully, the magic had also returned the pieces of him that the scavengers of the forest had plucked and gnawed away. But he was still coated in the gore of his death, the dirt of the wilderness, and horrible, discolored marks could be seen around his face, snaking into his hair matted with long-dried blood, and across his torso where his clothes had been rent in the fatal attack against him. Ugly claw marks, bite marks, sickening signs of impact. In time, however, his gasping breaths began to settle. He fumbled a moment, hands blindly groping into the grass and soil around himself, trying to push himself to sit upright, and trembling and wincing with the effort. Wide, horrified, bewildered eyes were pinned only on Kaleva, his marred chest heaving painfully. Silence stretched between them all, broken only by the ragged sounds of his breathing. Then, with a bit of difficulty, he choked out, "... I-Is she okay...?" (edited)
Dakota 7/14/2023 7:18 PM
Kaleva met Ludin's gaze at his question, and then slowly shook his head. He licked his lips, opened his mouth as if to speak... But his throat closed up again, forbidding any of the words from escaping, and so he looked helplessly to Ingrid to help explain the situation.
Daarka 7/14/2023 7:27 PM
Ludin stared in exponentially compounded horror. But Ingrid caught Kaleva's glance, and promptly looked to Ludin. "Welcome back, sunshine," she said evenly, a bit of her usual attitude slipping through--but with the mirth not quite making it to her expression, it came out a little more bitchy than charming. "Skena is dead. We workin' on fixin' that. That's ye debt tae pay now, from the sound've it, so ye new life's mission is tae fix that shite. An' we barely even know what bloody happened. So let's start there. We already talked tae ye corpse. That lil' shell ye left behind, or whatever it'd technically be what we were speakin' tae, said ye dinnae ken why ye did it. Said ye heard Skena callin' for ye, came tae see 'er, then ye just stuck a sword in 'er. We gonna need a bit more clarity than that." A beat. "But first of all: ye ken what this sword does?" It wasn't spoken like a curiosity, as she pointed a finger towards the weapon Kaleva's tail was wrapped around. It was spoken like scrutiny. Bordering on accusation. Ludin was... easily pinned down by her directness. His attention fixed on her, the matter-of-fact words dragging him up from the spiral of panic and horror he had started to slip down, because she simply didn't make room for such a meltdown. Still, it took him a moment to fumble his way to speech. "... Sword... I... N-No, I... I-I was told it'd... it'd keep me safe, I..."
Dakota 7/14/2023 7:32 PM
Kaleva appreciated Ingrid's directness in a lot of matters. Didn't dance around, didn't let Ludin spiral into whatever guilty panic he was going to get into. He dragged the sword around to take it into his hand, stabbing it into the ground for the time being, so that if anyone got any compulsion to wield it suddenly, himself included, they'd have a hard time pulling it out first.
Dakota 7/14/2023 7:45 PM
Overhead, there was the heavy beat of massive feathered wings, and Kaleva's head jerked up as Achoris' spindly form backwinged and landed heavily, his was scepter held tightly in his hand as he took in the group with narrowed black eyes. He hadn't met Ludin yet, but he knew the others well enough to trust they had the situation under control here. "Would someone like to explain to me why my niece's corpse is just laying around instead of in the hands of a healer returning her soul to her body? And for that matter, would someone also like to explain how she wound up that way in the first place??"
Daarka 7/14/2023 8:07 PM
Ludin's stammering was cut off by the new arrival, which he recoiled from reflexively--only to cringe in physical agony at the effort, wheezing several weak coughs that sounded wet. Ingrid and Cass both also glanced up as well, though neither looked horribly surprised to see this particular addition. "That is the question of the day," Cassiana murmured softly, unfazed by the heightened energy. Ingrid, however, understood that Kaleva was relying on her to be his voice where possible--and gods fucking damn it all, she took that job seriously. She set her tome and quill on the grass near Kaleva in case he needed them, before getting to her feet and dusting her hands off, facing Achoris. Through Ilex, they were well acquainted, and though he was highly averse to her usual approach towards men, she had clocked that from him early on, and cut him a break from her domineering, allowing them to exist around each other (and around Ilex) without friction. And he, more than anyone else present, would find her current demeanor the most shocking, given how much he had seen of her previously, how well he would have presumed to know her. And how all of the whimsy was utterly gone from her at the moment. "I imagine the diamond that just brought this one back," she said, gesturing to Ludin in a way that was not necessarily cold, but was also not compassionate, "Would have been spent on the wee lass long ago, but that isnae an option. As ye can fockin' imagine, Kaleva's in a state, so I donnae have all the answers, but this one," she pointed again, "ran 'er through with that blade. An' that one," she continued, now pointing at Kaleva (in a way that somehow did seem to have compassion behind it), "bashed this one's head in for it. Ah donnae ken what happened between then an' when I got involved. Ah had a shite feelin', an' I went tae see 'im. Couldnae find hide nor hair of anyone in the house, but found 'em out in the middle of buryin' the lass. I stopped 'im, 'cause that's sad as all fockin' shite an' I'm not gonna just sit there an' let that be how things are without spittin' in the face o' fate a little an' tryin' tae fix this clustershite. "An' Ah said the same thing," she continued pointedly. "We all know what the easy fix should have been. An' it isnae possible 'cause'a that rotten thing," a finger jabbed towards the sword again. "So then, first things first, we preserve the bloody situation. He leads me tae this one, an' she shields the wee lass from decay. Offers tae help, tae show the last seconds of her life, or speak tae her corpse. Kaleva only wanted tae know why it happened. So instead of either, we come here an' speak tae this crimson smear. He says he doesnae ken why. Says he's sorry. Says he remembers hearin' Skena call for 'em, he finds her, she greets 'em, then he runs her through, an' doesnae ken why. Kaleva wants tae ken if he's willin' tae try tae make things right. Corpse says aye. So some funky shite happens, an' now he's breathin' again, as of six minutes ago." The burning cyan of her eyes landed back on Ludin, who--perhaps predictably--looked mortified. "Moment ago, I asked if he knew what the sword did. Ah ken. Sounds like Kaleva does, too. This one says he doesnae ken. Says he was told it'd protect 'em. So, for the rest of ye, allow me tae illuminate the problem at hand: someone killed with that sword goes straight tae hell, and is reborn as a lemure. Maybe I'm horridly wrong, but I donnae think ye can return the soul tae the body if the soul found a new body." Her words were cold and flat. No lilting purr. No sass. Just a cold blade of a tongue. "... It's still possible," she continued, a fraction gentler. "But much, much, much harder. So we tryin' tae figure out what fockin' happened," she concluded, nodding firmly towards Ludin, "... An' then what tae do about it." A beat.
8:07 PM
She looked to Kaleva, that venom fully gone from her tone as she added, "If I'm missin' somethin', let me know, love."
Dakota 7/14/2023 8:23 PM
Achoris centered his void-black stare on Ludin as he was implicated in Skena's death, and brought the blade of his scepter beneath the man's chin to angle his face up to look at him, his wings fanning out as a black sand halo of vertical spikes misted around his crown. "Set came to my dreams a few nights ago and told me I needed to return here as quickly as possible. I don't believe He would do that if it were simply to inform me of Skena's death. She's His granddaughter. I trust that He and Anubis have something in mind for us." The words were directed at Kaleva, though he was still sizing up Ludin like he wanted to burn him in holy fire. Kaleva nodded, then paused as he realized Achoris wasn't... looking at him. So he reached out to tug on a wingtip, and when the aasimar looked at him, he tapped his holy symbol with a nod, and then held up his hand to Gummy to try to persuade him to cough up the hourglass. Achoris squinted at Gummy then, registering his perch on Kaleva's shoulders. "...That shouldn't be animate without Skena." Kaleva just nodded and tapped the holy symbol again. Anubis' doing. "Ah. He's been in touch with you, then?" (edited)

Dakota 7/14/2023 8:28 PM

Daarka 7/14/2023 8:34 PM
As it turned out, most of his voluntarily giving up his swallowed treasures appeared to happen because of Skena strong-arming it out of his psyche. In the absence of that, he was quite a little piece of shit. Like a cat inexplicably coveting a loaf of bread. But what he had in raw gumption, moxie, wherewithal, chutzpah, and above all, audacity, Gummy lacked in physical strength. He made several extremely awful sounds, much to the muted horror of Ludin, but Achoris was able to manhandle him and his easily-dislocated jaw, momentarily wearing the minion like a nightmare of a glove, before pulling free a small hourglass with black sand that always fell correctly, regardless of its position relative to gravity. Looking at it now... a little more than half the sand had fallen to the bottom half of the glass.
Dakota 7/14/2023 8:39 PM
"I don't know why she thinks you're cute. You're a vile, nasty little flesh pocket that can't decide if it's a cat or a snake." Achoris dumped Gummy back on Kaleva's shoulders, who seemed quite resigned to this state of affairs, and then held up the hourglass, turning it over in his hands to watch the sand fall up for a moment. "So, what happens when the time runs out?" Another tap at the amulet of Anubis, and a shrug. Achoris sighed and passed it back to Kaleva. "So we finish making preparations in the time we have left. Also, why aren't you speaking?" Kaleva glanced a little helplessly to Ingrid.
Daarka 7/14/2023 8:41 PM
Ingrid frowned, defensive on the tiefling's behalf. "'Cause the love of his life just fockin' died! He's bloody goin' through some'a the worst shite any of us could ever face! An' he's still soldierin' through with insane tenacity, so give the lad room tae handle it however he damn well chooses!"
Dakota 7/14/2023 8:45 PM
Achoris clicked his tongue. "Excuse me for asking. I didn't know he became mute in the face of trauma. Also, it's a temporary state of affairs. We have the guidance and backing of Gods in this venture. We're going to get her back." Kaleva held his hands up between them to try to quell the bickering, his lips pressed into a thin line. "Anyway, who all is going with us?"
Daarka 7/14/2023 8:48 PM
Ingrid cooled slightly as Achoris elaborated that he wasn't blaming Kaleva for his muteness and merely clarifying. Well, she'd rather accidentally bite a head off than have not defended the poor man when he needed it. "... Goin' where, exactly?" Ingrid's hands planted on her hips. "I agree with ye prognosis--but ye understand the kind of magic we talkin' about here? What'd be required tae retrieve her? At least in the ways I can wrack me brain figurin' out. Magic like that isnae in every town. Maybe not even every country. Folks what have it donnae exactly go handin' it out like pastries in a bakery, either."
Dakota 7/14/2023 9:04 PM
Achoris looked to Kaleva long enough to register his shrug, then looked back to Ingrid. "My guess is going to be Cusai. That's where Set and Anubis' pantheon is located, that's where They will be most familiar. And I have spent most of the last fifty or so years wandering those deserts and searching the ruins in the ever-shifting sands. Alternatively, They may also have us go to Hell to retrieve the lemure that Skena has become." Kaleva's head snapped up suddenly, and he went for the book Ingrid had set near him, scratching down quickly. 'Axa has drawn circles to summon imps into this realm before. Do you think she could summon Skena's lemure?' Achoris read the words he showed to them all, and frowned at the thought of interacting with Jaska or his daughter, or Valentine by association, but he wouldn't complain. "It would be worth asking. But we'd need a way to contain her safely until we could figure out how to purify her spirit and put her back in her body."
Daarka 7/14/2023 9:06 PM
Ingrid sucked in a long, contemplative breath, silent for a long moment as she thought. "... Dinnae... Miss Valentine ensnare an entire quasi-deity?" A beat. "Donnae ask me how I know that." (edited)
Dakota 7/14/2023 9:14 PM
"Then that should be our next stop," Achoris said with a curt nod, politely not asking how, indeed, she knew that. "Find out if Axa can summon Skena, and find out if Valentine can contain her until we figure out how to fix this." Kaleva scribbled more in the book, and then held it out to Ludin. 'There's little point in dragging you along at this moment. Stay with Cass and recover. We'll be back when there's a plan of action.'
Daarka 7/14/2023 9:19 PM
Ludin still looked shell-shocked and horrified beyond words, and a bit of blood was now dripping from one nostril. But he read over the text, looking up to Kaleva with... nothing but the most agonizing of apologies on his face. "... I-I'm... so sorry, Kaleva... I... didn't mean..." He wheezed a moment, then tightly swallowed. "... I'm... a fool. I should have... should have known. Or... at least... I should have... feared. I should have stayed away. I'm... I'm so sorry I... brought this on you." A beat. He swallowed again; it looked painful to do so. "... I'll... I'll help. However I can. I-I... I don't know what use I... even am. But I... I won't..." A long pause. "... I won't run."
Dakota 7/14/2023 9:23 PM
He pursed his lips, then wrote in the book again. 'Fenrir brought this on us. It's pointless for me to blame the weapon instead of the hand that guided it.' He hesitated, frowned, then wrote again. 'Sorry I killed you.'
Daarka 7/14/2023 9:25 PM
Despite the last comment being written and not even spoken, it still seemed to physically impact Ludin, and he wheezed forcibly, coughing up more blood as he recovered from the sudden seizing of his diaphragm. It was wet and painful and concerning... but as he settled again, the look on his face made it clear it had been a sort of humorless, shocked laughter. He stared at his son a moment in silence, before mumbling, "... I think I deserved it."
Dakota 7/14/2023 9:27 PM
Kaleva shrugged at him with a wince. Achoris let out a dry snort, then looked to Cassiana. "Do you mind keeping an eye on him?"
Daarka 7/14/2023 9:31 PM
Cass had been listening along placidly, naturally the most emotionally void of all of them. Save, perhaps, for Gummy. "That is no trouble to me," she replied easily, slowly beginning the process of carefully getting back to her feet. "I fear there is little I can do to help with the pursuits you have been discussing, though I wish I could. I am sure my husband would share that sentiment. If this is how we can productively contribute, then you have our word, he will be in good hands." She paused a moment, a brief somatic gesture betraying her reaching out to her husband again. 'Can you come to meet me on the path to their cottage? I could use your assistance. I will explain in person.'
Dakota 7/14/2023 9:36 PM
Achoris offered his hand under Cass's corporeal arm to assist her in standing while she did her thing. Nils' reply was immediate. 'I'm on my way.' Taking in a shuddering breath, Kaleva closed the book and hugged it to his chest, stressed and jittery, but grateful for a plan of action. The more things took shape, the more hope began to nestle into his heart. He gave one last nod to Cass and Ludin, and then turned to Ingrid, his tail curling around hers as he gave her a questioning look, wondering if she was going to continue to stick with them.
Daarka 7/14/2023 9:51 PM
Cass nodded, her gaze lingering a moment on Kaleva. "... Take it from me, my friend: death is an abstract thing." She gave him a soft, understanding smile. "The love that those left behind carry in their hearts can move heaven and earth. In time... things tend to make sense. Keep your faith close. And you," she continued, looking to Ludin, who had very agonizingly begun to rouse to his feet, "I'm afraid I am little good for physical support, and the walk is not far, but it will feel farther on the body of a corpse. I can also attest to that," she added wryly. "But my husband will meet us soon. And he will ease your travels better than I could." She cocked her head slightly, eyes squinting at the man a moment. Ludin precariously steadied himself on his feet, returning her gaze... and for the first time, really took in her appearance. And then the recognition set in. "Ah, there it is. All things in time, though. Come; you need not go faster than you are able, but let us begin our little trek." Ludin was... disturbed. But grateful, at least, for the opportunity to just focus on existing in that moment, and face further interrogations later. When he wasn't breathing his own viscera. As they began a very unhurried hobble away, Ingrid looked over at the brush of Kaleva's tail, and she exhaled shortly with a soft smile and a sympathetic tilt of her head. "... Beloved, I promised ye I'd help. When ye ask me tae leave, that's when I'm gone. Come on, then." She gestured through the trees, back towards his home. "... In fact... ye bloody hate most'a that family, aye?" She wondered, glancing at Achoris. "Why donnae ye stay here with this one, the two of ye just breathe a bit. I'll go fetch Jaska." She knew the man was... fond of Skena. The emotions she expected this news to draw out of him were not beneficial to either of the men currently at her side. And Achoris' presence would just be overtly antagonistic to Jaska, no matter what Achoris did or did not do. Him being there at all would likely just make things worse. And Kaleva wasn't even speaking. "Put on some tea. Breathe. Let me do the errandwork for a minute."
Dakota 7/14/2023 10:07 PM
Kaleva nodded slowly, and Achoris let out a faint snort. "Probably for the best. We'll bide, then, while you deal with that end of things." His wings folded back into nothingness, though the black sands of his halo remained, and he turned to begin back toward the cabin, Kaleva following in his wake at Ingrid's side, his tail still loosely curled with hers and carrying the book and hourglass against his chest.
Daarka 7/14/2023 10:12 PM
Ingrid walked close enough for her shoulder to be against his side, and as they stepped back inside, she reached to rub her hand softly over his back. "Hang on tae that for now, beloved. Ye might need it, an' I won't for now. I'll be quick as I can; I imagine he won't want tae dally, either." She looked past him to meet Achoris' gaze, a gentle look on her face that seemed to say, Take care of him. Please. Almost apologetically, she pulled away from Kaleva, disappearing briskly out the door and into her own shop again. As quickly as she could, she gave Arsast the rundown of what was going on, just so he would know why she was gone for so long. And would probably stay gone for a while longer. She... didn't like burdening him with such potent bummers. But he was a big boy, and he deserved to be informed, too. She disappeared after that, making her way with unusual speed to Jaska's residence, and giving the door a series of short, sharp knocks.
Dakota 7/14/2023 10:19 PM
Much like Ingrid, Arsast also knew when to drop the gremlin behavior and put on his serious face. He nodded solemnly at what she told him, and told her he'd hold down the fort until she was able to return. He then went to turn his nervous, fidgety energy into searching the shop for something that might work as a receptacle for Skena that could potentially be enchanted to keep her in place, in the event that something else wasn't already on hand. At Jaska's residence, he glanced up from his schooling lessons with Axa, rising to his feet and making his way to the door. A glance out the window showed Ingrid there, but when he opened the door, one glance was enough to know something was up. "...What is it, what's wrong?"
Daarka 7/14/2023 10:21 PM
She looked up at him like she wanted to smile in greeting, but simultaneously didn't have the patience for it. "Can I come in? I need tae share some shite with ye, an' it's annoyin'ly nuanced, so I need tae say it all in one breath tae do it justice."
Dakota 7/14/2023 10:24 PM
He stepped aside and motioned her in, his brow furrowing with concern. "Yes, of course." He didn't bother to offer her a drink or anything, it didn't seem like she was in a mood for niceties. Once she was inside, he closed the door and turned to her expectantly.
Daarka 7/14/2023 10:39 PM
Ingrid stepped in, but shook her head as he just stood there, instead pointing to the nearest seat. "Sit down for this. An' wait for me tae get it all out before reactin'. Please." She waited for him to oblige, glancing to Axa where she was standing off nearby, staring at her blankly. The notion that this child could summon things from hell was a new one for Ingrid; she had thus far still been in the dark on that front. But one thing at a time. She looked back to Jaska, inhaling as she quickly collected her thoughts. She hadn't ever exactly imagined herself being this kind of bearer of bad news, and it was probably the most uncomfortable she'd been in this situation thus far. "... We still workin' on figurin' out some of the details of what happened. What we know is that Skena was killed. Kaleva then killed the man who did it. Turns out, that man had no idea what was goin' on, an' somethin' else was compellin' him tae do it. Just got back from helpin' that elf with the focked-up arm resurrect 'im at Kaleva's request. Resurrection--in the more straightforward sense--isnae an option for Skena. She was killed with a weapon that sent her soul straight tae hell, where it was presumably made a lemure out of. So there's no soul adrift, nothin' tae resurrect. But we have options," she emphasized. "Not as many options as we normally would. Achoris showed up, he's just as bull-headed about this as I am, an' Plan A right now looks tae be some manner of acquirin' the Skena-lemure, safely confinin' it, an' then seekin' out the high magic that could potentially reverse that reincarnation. The knee-jerk reaction was that ye sister might be resourceful somewhere in that. An' somethin' about ye little one--summonin' shite from hell?" She squinted a little. Evidently she still didn't know why that made sense to Kaleva. She paused, taking a moment to gauge Jaska's reaction. "... We got a small army already, prepared tae move some mountains tae fix this," she added, a bit softer. "Do ye have ideas that could help us do that?"
Dakota 7/17/2023 6:14 PM
Jaska normally had an expression on his face that was borderline sour in a way that always seemed to carry a degree of tension, like he was always keyed up and ready for confrontation. And as he sat at Ingrid's request, leaning forward with fingers loosely interlaced between his knees, his lips pursed into a thin line. When she told him Skena had been killed, it was like the wire holding every line of tension in his face was cut. His face went slack with shock, his lips parting, his eyes wide and unfocusing as his one visible pupil flicked back and forth. An exhale punched out of him as the information continued to bombard him. That she could not be resurrected, that she was in Hell, and currently existed as a molten mass of flesh that existed to suffer torment. A shaking hand slowly lifted to cup over his gaping mouth, his ashen lavender skin gone far too pale. He was silent for a good while, but she had come with suggestions, directions he could take that took that helpless feeling of loss and gave it direction. He held up a finger as if to ask Ingrid for patience, and thumbed the ring that would instigate Valentine to open a mental connection. Once he heard her voice in his head, he responded - his tone one she never would have heard from him before, bleak and shaken. 'How quickly can you devise a means of safely containing a lemure? And secondly, do you know of any means of... undoing the transformation of a soul into a lemure?'
Daarka 7/17/2023 6:46 PM
Ingrid's grim lack of whimsy softened with quiet sympathy as he processed. She knew this whole clusterfuck of people involved in the issue at hand largely would find pure consolations to be a waste of time and breath, to feel hollow at best, alienating at worst. She had... never quite experienced loss like this firsthand. But she knew people. She knew the first brush of grief was denial--and if that denial was validated, given room to take root, given realistic footing in things that could truly deny the loss... the rest need not be suffered. When he held up his finger, she dipped her chin slightly. He could take however long he needed. It was a lot to process. Axa didn't... understand the emotions of what was transpiring. But she wasn't stupid. Far more than the average child, she could follow what was being explained (though with some difficulty; Ingrid's accent wasn't always easy for her to parse). And the look on her father's face was... quietly distressing. She stared at him, the tip of her tail flicking slightly, suspended on that precipice of trying to ascertain if she herself should be stressed based on how the next moments unfolded. When she heard his voice, Valentine's own shifted on a dime. Somehow managing to translate that whatever she was doing, wherever she was, regardless of her inhuman ability to multitask... it had all be dropped and this had her full, undivided attention. '... Perhaps... an hour or two to collect reagents, and brush up on some arcana to ensure I do it correctly. I would want to discuss such an endeavor with Luka; it's what he and I studied together, and he has a good mind for catching any errors I may be making. But undoing a transformation...' there was a long, deep breath. '... I do not know how at the moment.' A beat. 'But I figured out how to separate you and Luka. In time... I would be... fairly confident I could manage something adjacent, as you describe.' It had taken years to sort out her brother's conundrum; there was no purpose in pointing that out, though. They had both suffered all the interim, Jaska was perfectly aware of how long it took. '... What has happened, Jaska? Do you need me to come to you?'
Dakota 7/17/2023 6:55 PM
'I would... prefer your efforts currently go toward reaching out to Luka and preparing a containment.' There was a sort of gasping quality to the words he sent to her mind, as though even his mental speech struggled for breath, as though he were drowning. 'Skena was killed with a weapon that... sent her soul to Hell and turned her into a lemure. I need to ask Axa if it's... possible for her to summon Skena.'
