When you were very young, your caretakers sought to create a manner of safety net for you, should anything horrible befall you. The hope was that it would never need to exist, but if you are reading this, then those efforts were immensely wise indeed. Something succeeded in killing you. This letter has been penned far in advance of your reading it, and so I cannot explain those circumstances. But instead of your soul passing to the afterlife, the precautions set in place for you here redirected its path, and delivered it into the body you currently exist in. This body is a perfect clone of the one you have previously spent your life in--and your soul, along with your memories and personality and everything that makes you who you are, have been implanted into it. Any attempts to revive your original body will have failed, as your soul is no longer adrift. You currently reside in a demiplane created by the archmage tasked with creating this safeguard for you. Nothing will harm you here. I am sure the circumstances that brought you here are upsetting; try to relax and recover as needed. Your awakening has triggered enchantments that have alerted me to it having taken place, and rest assured, I am doing everything in my power to get you home as you read this. Given the unique manner of your arrival, I cannot present you with any of your personal belongings. Given the nature of this demiplane, you will not be able to leave of your own accord, either. As soon as is physically possible, however, I will be traveling to your home, and will open the portal to this plane at that point, allowing you to be back where you belong. I will be as expeditious as possible, but apologize for the interim all the same. You are free to explore anything and everything of this demiplane while you wait. If you are hungry or thirsty, simply speak your desires, and the fortress itself will see to your needs. My homunculus is a sphinx by the name of Amara who resides here as well, and will likely seek you out shortly to be of further assistance. My immediate priority is getting you home. I ask your forgiveness in that I am not coming to speak with you first and answer any further questions you may have, but due to the demands of the magic that allows me access to this demiplane, such a visit would substantially delay my ability to bring you home. If you wish it, we will have time to speak once you are returned to where you belong, as it is my assumption that this is a priority for you as well. Again, I reiterate: please do your best to relax and recover. Ask anything of the sanctum, and it will do its best to provide for you. If all goes smoothly, we will speak soon. -Amunet Skena read it over. Then again. Three times. So not... in hell, then? She wanted so badly to let the relief roll over her, but... back where you belong Her throat still felt so dry. An old proverb began to echo endlessly in the corners of her mind, an idiom picked up from studies in her youth. Incidit in scyllam cupiens vitare charybdim; "He runs on Scylla, wishing to avoid Charybdis". Out of the frying pan, and into the fire.
5:14 PM
The demiplane that Amunet opened the doorway to turned out to be, at least at its entrance, a fairly large, beautiful hall. Smooth sandstone tiles made up the floor, with matching pillars rising up in parallel rows down either side of the path. It was dimly lit in a cozy, pleasant way, and the walls to the left and right of the center path were only occasionally interrupted by wide archways leading to offshooting rooms, with royal blue curtains draped from them, but tied to the side to allow entry. At the end of the hall, a wide set of stairs led up to a landing. From that landing, stairways only half as wide branched off to either side; one to the left, one to the right, leading to a second floor that was not visible from the first. Potentially most noteworthy was that this space was not empty of life--but it was not Skena who occupied it. Laying off to the side of the hall like a large, cat-like alien was a unique, striking creature. It had a long, narrow body, walking on four legs--but with an additional pair of limbs close behind the front legs, smaller, and tucked up against the ribs. And those front legs were... perhaps more like arms, as they seemed to end in rather humanoid hands. Likewise, a long, nearly serpentine neck lifted elegantly to a mostly humanoid face, crested in long feathers framing it, and bony growths that might have been horns sprouting from its temples--but unlike horns, these growths joined at their tips, forming a smooth arc that very nearly resembled a halo. Perhaps even more notably, this strange creature looked... possibly wounded? It was hard to say, for there was no blood, no typical signs of a bodily injury. But something looked impactful and horribly wrong about one side of their torso, and sinister black veins seemed to branch out from that point like a creeping rot.
SPOILER
5:14 PM
The sphinx looked up as Kaleva darted into the hall, with Amunet quickly following suit behind him. But at the sight of the strange creature, she paused, blinking at it in shock. "... Is--?" "She has strongly rejected any of our assistance," the sphinx murmured back, her voice low and rasping in an oddly soft, almost pleasant way. "Our presence seems to cause distress, and so we have left her to wander. We believe she was last noticed in the library." If the awful markings on the creature were an injury, the sphinx at least did not act as if they were in pain, even giving a polite dip of their head to Kaleva as well. Amunet was moving again as soon as that information was received. "I will mend you later. Thank you, Amara." Her boots clicked with rhythmic purpose across the sandstone, and she led Kaleva to the stairs, which were scaled with that same, unwavering forward momentum. If he looked around them as they moved, he would see the stairs branching to the left led directly and solely to a beautiful ivory door with golden accents. At the center of the door, at about eye level, the carvings of the door that were otherwise mostly decorative instead took the more deliberate shape of what appeared to be an elegant pot, with its opening tilted downwards, and the likeness of water pouring from within and snaking down the rest of the door's carvings like the roots of a tree made possible by a gorgeous blue gem of some sort, inlaid into the ivory. This door was ajar, halfway swung out towards the stairs, but the room within too dimly lit to properly see into as they quickly moved along; Amunet spared a fleeting glance towards it, but led Kaleva up the stairs to the right. That path brought them to a large, wonderfully cozy space perfect for lounging, filled with a plethora of invitingly cushy pillows and seating, including a recessed area of the floor with an especially high concentration of rugs and pillows, creating a pit of welcoming comfort. A complex, enchanted display of the night sky made up what should have been a ceiling, but there was little time to take it all in; Amunet kept up her brisk pace, headed to the side of this room, and through another open archway.
5:15 PM
Down a comparatively more narrow hall this time. One accented with the occasional door or open archway along its walls. But instead of passing through any of them, Amunet led him straight down to the end of the hall, where it simply opened up into another massive space. At a glance, it was easily identifiable as a library. Immense shelves stacked with innumerable books of all shapes, sizes, and varieties made up every wall, and created several rows in the empty space between them. None of that would have properly registered in Kaleva's mind. Instead, what both he and Amunet saw as soon as they rounded the corner to enter this new space was a figure whipping around to face them. The body was small... but its current presence was not. A black miasma rippled out from her form, almost more of her complexion seeming black than white with how many dark eyes had opened across her skin. Her features were shadowed and alien, the air around her seeming to shiver--like a distant heat wave, but without any heat to blame. Strange black markings snaked across what flesh could even be seen between the eyes, and as she whirled to face her visitors, those blacked out eyes pinned on Amunet, empty hands held out in the air as if braced to summon some horrible magic. The elf didn't even get a chance to speak. "Don't you dare come a single gods-damned step closer‚ÄîI'll choke the wretched life out of you with my bare hands, I'm not‚Äî" Her voice echoed in a haunting, otherworldly way; it might have even reminded Kaleva of a time she had been burning in holy fire of her own making--but there was no canid snarl behind her words this time. And her uncharacteristically vitriolic threats choked out of her as she seemed to realize... this elf was not alone. For a moment, there was only stunned silence. "... K... Kaleva...?" The horrific echo of her voice remained, even as her tone wilted to something that sounded... so much smaller. There were no pupils in her eyes, but it was undeniable that every single one was staring at the tiefling unblinkingly. In that brief stillness, it was clear she was shaking terribly. She had been from before they even walked in.
Dakota 7/22/2023 6:10 PM
The sound that came from Kaleva's throat was a mewling thing, a noise of such heartbreakingly keen relief as tears spilled down his face. He was rushing forward in an instant to gather her up in his arms, falling to his knees to bury his face in her, wracking sobs tearing from him as he broke down completely. Atreyu, following close on their heels, let out a similar barking cry and rushed forward to curl around them, shaking and covering them both in frantic kisses, his body wiggling with an inability to control his own emotions.
Daarka 7/22/2023 6:21 PM
"Kaleva!" The name that ripped from her was nothing short of a wail, and she threw herself into him with equal intensity, clinging to him impossibly tight and devolving into sobs that nearly screamed out of her. Somewhere in the tangle of bodies, the unsettling changes to her appearance gradually drained away, until all that was left was the simple, expected appearance of the little aasimar, wearing a plain, off-white dress, and with the crown of her head dusted in subtle golden shimmers. She was still shaking horribly, her breathing shallow and gasping between cries that were practically painful to hear with how deeply, deeply raw and intense they were. At some point, the sobs began to form to words, wobbly and gasping and broken though they were. "P-Please don't--let them take me, I-I want to--I wanna go home," she whimpered, sounding like... a scared, lost child. Her scent was... just slightly different than Kaleva was used to. It was fundamentally the scent of Skena... but it lacked the environmental things she had picked up in their lives. It was almost like a sterilized version of her scent, with virtually no inherent information woven into it that spoke of where she had been, no residual scent of the dogs she had lived with, or the sugar she existed off of.
Dakota 7/22/2023 6:36 PM
He didn't have words. Those were still lost to his ability to vocalize, though the wretched keening still kept up. But he had actions, had other means to comfort and reassure her, and as he gathered her up into his arms, those arms grew bigger, stronger, and covered in black fur. Scooping her up and holding her protectively, the fur of his cheeks still wet with tears and his huge triangular ears pressed back and low, he turned to start to take her back out of this place. Because bringing her home was the single most important thing right now. Atreyu got up to follow, though he kept skittering on ahead before looping back, passing them in a fit of zoomies, little excited whimpers peppering out of him.
Daarka 7/22/2023 6:43 PM
Skena clung to him, arms wrapped tightly around his neck, still wracked with gasping sobs. But finally feeling some small measure of relief wash over her, at least. Amunet had stood back as they reunited, watching with a softly bittersweet expression. As Kaleva gathered Skena up and made to leave, she stepped aside to not block his path, following after him, while allowing him a comfortable radius of personal space. As he made his way back down the main stairway, he would be met halfway by Ingrid, who had seemingly decided that respecting his privacy was secondary to making sure he was safe, and hadn't just dove into some trap. At the sight of Skena in his arms, her shoulders sagged with relief, her demeanor relaxing considerably, and as he reached her position, she turned to walk alongside him back out, a hand gently rubbing across his back. Nothing would stop them from exiting back into the cozy little woodland cottage again, Amunet allowing them all to exit first before following behind them. She, too, looked as though some manner of weight had been lifted from her heart, though she quieted and stood out of the way to allow the two to settle back in to their home properly.
Dakota 7/22/2023 7:14 PM
When Kaleva stepped back through the portal with Skena, the looks of abject relief flashed across several of the faces present. Achoris wasted no time getting right in to reach in and cradle Skena's face in his hands, pressing his forehead to hers and closing his eyes. "Scared the blazes out of all of us," he whispered, long fingers digging into her hair. "COOKIES," Arsast suddenly blurted, and ran off to go fetch them from the room Skena's other body was being held in. Luka stood by with his hand over his mouth and tears in his eyes, his other arm around Valentine's shoulders, sniffling a bit wetly and smiling with relief. Jaska, on the other hand, permitted himself a moment to close his eyes and let his shoulders slump, let the relief heal the ache that had been ever-present since he'd heard the news, and quietly moved back to be out of the way of things.
Daarka 7/22/2023 7:21 PM
Skena's sobs had devolved into shaky, stuffy-nosed hyperventilating, and she blinked slightly as Achoris' hands slid around her face, only then realizing just... how many people were gathered in their home. Her face was still twisted in a nearly primal sort of anxiety, and she still looked on edge. Still waiting for the other shoe to drop. "... I-I'm... s-sorry... Kaleva, I'm--sorry," she choked, fingers knotting in his fur. "I'm sorry--"
Dakota 7/22/2023 7:26 PM
Kaleva could only shake his head as he pressed it into her shoulder, still carrying her in his arms. Achoris exhaled and rested his hands on both her shoulder and Kaleva's. "Nothing that happened was your choice, Skena. No one is blaming you. You're not at fault for anything. We're just glad things weren't as dire as we thought they would be."
Daarka 7/22/2023 7:31 PM
"I-I'm sorry," she choked again, burying her face in Kaleva's cheek. "I-I left--you alone, I'm--I'm so sorry--" Ingrid winced softly as she watched, hesitating a moment... before a delicate somatic gesture was woven through the air. An instant later, Skena's anxiety seemed to ebb back, her death grip relaxing slightly on Kaleva. Her breaths were still spasming a bit, but she started actually working to settle them, suddenly just seeming... exhausted. Deeply, deeply exhausted. "There now, love. Think we all need tae just take a moment an' breathe."
Dakota 7/22/2023 7:54 PM
Giving Ingrid a small nod, Kaleva went to bring Skena to the bedroom, Atreyu sitting in the doorway to block others from entering. He set her down and let the transformation fade, bundling her in his arms and sitting against the headboard, his fingers running soothingly through her hair. While they went to get some privacy to process things, Achoris sighed and turned to Amunet. "Thank you for bringing her here. I am curious to know the circumstances around there just being an extra body lying around for her to inhabit in the event of the death of the original."
Daarka 7/22/2023 8:14 PM
Skena gradually worked to catch her breath over the next several, long minutes, her hands settling on either side of Kaleva's face. "... Am I gonna wake up?" She breathed painfully after a while, her eyes still watery. Amunet turned her attention to Achoris, dipping her chin a little, her expression a little somber, but still relieved. "When she was an infant, a sample of flesh was taken from her. The memory of the procedure was erased so she need not be traumatized from it, and the wound was quickly healed. But from that sample, a clone was able to be developed. It grew alongside her, perfectly replicating the body she ultimately developed; an empty vessel, enchanted to intercept her soul if it was loosed from its original body, before it would transition beyond the veil. I then placed enchantments around this clone's containment, so that I would be alerted if it ever became animate. I... left a note for her, attempting to explain all of these things, but I wrote it many years ago. I do not know how she died, only the manner in which her soul would be recovered." A beat. "Admittedly, I did not foresee her being this distressed. Dying would be understandably traumatic, but... I almost wonder if she somehow failed to see the note." She sounded... a bit self-critical about it. Like there was a failure somewhere in that presumed miscommunication, and she was to blame for it.
Dakota 7/22/2023 10:38 PM
Kaleva shook his head gently between her hands, gathering her in close and peppering her face with soft kisses, his own eyes still watery, bags of exhaustion evident underneath them. "Mm. I have an idea why, but before I go into that... I'd really like my previous questions answered. For Skena's safety. I know you've brought her here, and Ikiro says you're trustworthy, but I think a lot of us would breathe better if we knew who you were in all of this." Achoris gestured to the couch. "Sit if you like. There's tea, milk, or coffee. Food if you're hungry." "Er... Introductions, perhaps?" Luka piped up with a gentle smile, approaching Amunet with an extended hand. "Thank you for everything you've done. I am Luka, and these are my siblings Valentine and Jaska, and my niece, Axa. These are Achoris, Ingrid, and Arsast. We are all dear friends of Skena."
Daarka 7/22/2023 10:50 PM
Skena sucked in a shaky inhale, Ingrid's enchantment keeping her from the spiral she very much would still be on otherwise. "... As... soon as I relax... I know... all this will go away," she squeaked. "I can't... think of any more... fitting way to be... brought into hell. If it's... meant to be torment... I..." She had cried herself into exhaustion, but her fingers tightened slightly on him again anyways. "... Please be real. Please... I'll... I'll never have a... a hope of being okay ever again if... if this isn't real..." Amunet glanced over to Luka, offering him a gentle, compassionate smile, and reaching to return his handshake. "... I apologize. You're quite right. I did not think it appropriate to waste breath on formalities before Skena was returned home. But my name is Amunet, and it is... a deep pleasure to meet all of you. I am endeared to see how quickly so many friends gathered to support these two throughout this." She looked back to Achoris, sighing softly. "Skena will return to Cautica over my dead body," she said simply. "I am not here on the business of the temples. And there is no one else alive who even knows this clone had been created for her. Save for you all, now," she added with a distant note of amusement. She met Achoris' gaze squarely. "I am no friend of Oberon's." A pause. "A very long time ago, I knew Skena's mother. But that is, respectfully, between the girl and I. Hopefully that illuminates my motivations better, however." (edited)
Dakota 7/25/2023 10:15 PM
Again Kaleva shook his head, and he struggled to force his voice past the seizure of his vocal chords, finally managing a raspy, stilted croak. "Real. It... felt like Hell... when you..." Swallowing, he held her tighter, almost like he could merge her body into his own. "This is real. Your... body's... in your workshop." Achoris relaxed significantly at her statement, and off to the side, Jaska's tense posture also became slightly less so. "Then you should understand, she may have felt that, if these preventative measures were put into place when she was young, that might also mean that she had awakened back in the grasp of someone working for Oberon. She might have thought she was back in Cautica."
Daarka 7/25/2023 10:27 PM
Skena gave the faintest twitch of a wince at that, easily being smushed up against the tiefling. She fell silent again, her shaking reduced to small trembles as she worked on catching her breath and just‚Ä¶ soaking in the scent of him. Amunet frowned thoughtfully. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ If memory serves, the letter did not mention the temple or anyone associated. I had written that I was bringing her back home.‚Äù She sighed softly. ‚ÄúI can see where there might have been the misunderstanding, though. I owe her an apology.‚Äù
Dakota 7/25/2023 10:33 PM
"Perhaps something that can wait for another night." Achoris glanced to the bedroom doorway. "Agreed," Luka said softly, cradling his elbows in his palms. "I think they might just need some quiet and normalcy right now. But we'll be on standby if we wind up being needed." Jaska straightened somewhat. "Didn't Anubis tell Kaleva He had a task for him? That seems like it'd be more than... 'be at home ready to comfort Skena.' I feel like this isn't finished yet." He glanced toward the Hellfire longsword with narrowed eyes.
Daarka 7/25/2023 10:35 PM
Amunet blinked at Jaska‚Äôs input, tilting her head slightly. ‚ÄúAnubis speaks to him?‚Äù She asked after a moment, her tone‚Ä¶ almost sounding‚Ä¶ endeared?
Dakota 7/25/2023 10:38 PM
Jaska blinked, then sniffed faintly. "Seems to have adopted him as one of His own, from what I understand." Arsast, meanwhile, was cleaning up the remnants of the food, though he did arrange a plate for Amunet in case she was hungry, and put the rest in the icebox.
Daarka 7/25/2023 10:41 PM
Amunet‚Äôs gaze softened slightly at that, a gentle smile touching her features. She paused as the plate was offered to her, blinking. ‚ÄúOh, thank you, this looks wonderful,‚Äù she murmured, graciously accepting it and heading over to daintily sit on the nearest available seating. (edited)
Dakota 7/25/2023 10:45 PM
The satyr's tail wagged, and he beamed a toothy grin at her. "Made it myself! I promise you won't get food poisoning!" Jaska's eye twitched, and Luka let out a snort. "Well, the rest of us haven't gotten food poisoning yet, so I can at least confirm that somewhat worrying declaration." Achoris went to sit perched on the arm of the couch, ankle crossed over knee. "So how, exactly, have you kept abreast of Skena's situation in Cautica? She's never mentioned you before and clearly has no idea who you are."
Daarka 7/25/2023 10:53 PM
Amunet paused, before giving Arsast a charmed smile. ‚ÄúAlright, I‚Äôll trust you,‚Äù she agreed easily, scooping up a bite onto her fork. As Achoris questioned her, she chewed and swallowed the bite she had taken before responding. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Out of respect to her mother, I tried to keep an eye on her from afar,‚Äù she replied after a thoughtful pause. ‚ÄúI am no friend of Oberon‚Äôs‚Ä¶ but we are well acquainted, and have rubbed elbows in overlapping social circles for many years. He‚Ä¶ knows who I am, in relation to Skena.‚Äù A beat. ‚ÄúI would have liked to support the girl properly, but he did not think my presence in her life would be in her best interest. He had his reasons, I suppose,‚Äù she drawled, the unenthusiastic lidding of her eyes betraying how little she seemed to think of those reasons. ‚ÄúI did not want to make it harder for myself to keep watch over her by making an enemy out of her caregivers, so I kept watch from afar. I imagine she may recognize me for the same reasons you did,‚Äù she added, nodding casually to Achoris, ‚Äúbut she has not known me personally, no.‚Äù
Dakota 7/25/2023 10:59 PM
Achoris accepted that with a nod and settled in to wait and see what else might come. The muffled murmur of talking out in the living room was an oddly comforting backdrop to the quiet safety of the bedroom, the various voices of their friends as they stood watchful vigil. Kaleva lay curled on his side, running his fingers through Skena's hair, chest to chest, his heart beating against hers. He kept occasionally leaning down to rub his cheek and jaw against her, canine instincts insisting he start swaying her scent to something less sterile and more familiar, and Atreyu was a warm, furry weight curled around them.
Daarka 7/25/2023 11:03 PM
Skena didn‚Äôt seem to mind his rubbing, and as the minutes dragged on, she slowly settled down more and more. By the time Ingrid‚Äôs calming spell had worn off, she was‚Ä¶ mostly okay. Mostly. There was still a horrible jitteriness in the back of her mind. A tension. Still waiting for the other shoe to drop. Still not‚Ä¶ fully convinced. Swallowing tightly, she faintly croaked, ‚Äú‚Ä¶ I-I need to go‚Ä¶ ask Axa something.‚Äù But her gentle grip on him did not release.
Dakota 7/25/2023 11:07 PM
Kaleva blinked, then nodded slowly and rolled toward the edge of the bed - though with Skena still in his arms, he just wound up rolling her with him, up over the top of him and to the other side so they could slowly clamber out of bed together. Atreyu was right at their heels, stretching and letting out a warbling yawn, not about to let either of them out of his sight.
Daarka 7/25/2023 11:51 PM
Skena stirred to get back to her feet, though did so while maintaining as much physical contact as possible. With her hand clasped snugly in Kaleva‚Äôs, she very hesitantly stepped out of the bedroom with him. There were‚Ä¶ so many faces. She wanted to find comfort in them. But she didn‚Äôt look at any of them, because she wouldn‚Äôt be able to bear it if that comfort was proven illusory. Instead, she immediately located Axa, who was curled up on Jaska‚Äôs lap; one of the few people present who didn‚Äôt look to her at her appearance. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Axa?‚Äù Skena managed, barely more than a whisper. At that, Axa‚Äôs ear twitched, and she turned her head to glance expressionlessly in Skena‚Äôs direction. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ How can I prove to myself that I‚Äôm not in hell?‚Äù Skena whispered, the words nearly choking in her throat. Axa stared at her a long moment, turning that question over. Her gaze ultimately shifted just‚Ä¶ slightly adjacent to Skena, as if to look at the air framing her body instead of her. Then she settled back in against Jaska. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ There aren‚Äôt gods in hell,‚Äù she mumbled quietly, her tone (usually a rather emotionless thing) actually sounding a little disdainful or annoyed about it. Skena took a few breaths, her gaze jerking towards the shrine in the dining room after a moment. Grip tightening on Kaleva, she headed in that direction, her posture tense and anxious as she slumped down to her knees, fumbling with the matches laid out there to light one, and then use it to light the incense also set on that small shelf. Her hands began to shake again, her breathing getting a little shallow despite herself, as she realized that this not turning out how it should would lead to her coming entirely and permanently undone. It took her longer than it otherwise would have to shape the magic into the ritual; she was struggling to keep calm, and still did not have her amulet, leaving her casting without a focus. This made it border on being impossible, but‚Ä¶ she didn‚Äôt seem to realize that was the element working against her, too anxious and tunnel-visioned. And as she strained to channel the magic properly‚Ä¶ there was a subtle saving grace, as the amulet Kaleva wore, so close in proximity, seemed to act as the necessary conduit instead. Skena‚Äîand Kaleva‚Äîalone would feel the gentle rush of warm, desert wind. And within the span of a heartbeat, they looked up to find themselves in that stretch of sand under a nighttime sky filled with an impossible number of stars. The full moon hung overhead‚Äîno, not full. It had begun to wane by a thin sliver. The otherworldly sensation here was like no other‚Äînor was the presence of Anubis, who stood before them with a patient softness. Skena stared at Him speechlessly for a long moment, overwhelmed with the hope that swelled in her with feeling that unmistakeable presence. She was positive that feeling of pure divinity could not be imitated. But she finally asked her question anyways. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm really‚Ä¶ safe‚Ä¶?‚Äù She whispered breathlessly. Anubis‚Äô eyes‚Äîgold as He looked upon His daughter‚Äîsoftened, and He stepped forward, kneeling and stooping down towards her. His muzzle slid between her head and Kaleva‚Äôs, His hand gently cradling the other side of her face. ‚Ä¶ There is much that lies ahead. But your lives are to be full, and your ends peaceful. What left is there to fear? The deep velvet of His voice gently stirred their hair, and He tenderly nuzzled Skena‚Äôs cheek a moment, before slowly leaning back again. As all the lingering anxiety and fear did then bleed out of Skena, her hand settled on the back of His where it rested against her face. She stared up at Him, soaking in that peace that she was so starved of. Finally taking deep breaths.
Daarka 7/26/2023 12:15 AM
The ritual afforded her three questions, but it was hard to think of how to best utilize those. There had been only one that mattered at first, but it felt wasteful to not ask the others in the wake of such confusing events. It took her a moment nonetheless to sort out her scattered thoughts. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ That‚Ä¶. That woman, the‚Ä¶ the place I woke up in‚Ä¶‚Äù she swallowed again, the memory still raw. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶ grateful, if she saved me, but I‚Ä¶‚Äù she paused, her brow furrowing as realization slowly set in. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ I-I think I‚Äôve seen her before‚Ä¶ in Cautica‚Ä¶‚Äù she looked back up to Anubis. ‚ÄúIs it‚Ä¶ okay for her to be here?‚Äù Anubis exhaled gently, an almost sleepily amused sound. Amunet has a good heart. You will see it as I do. There is nothing she cannot be trusted with. Skena blinked at the‚Ä¶ unexpectedly high praise. Her gaze wandered the celestial realm around them for a moment, as she struggled to think. To figure out the last, most pressing question she could identify. Something‚Ä¶ tugged at the back of her mind. Something that didn‚Äôt sit right in her memory, but hadn‚Äôt been given proper thought yet with the way her psyche had been occupied since awakening. Her brow furrowed in silence as she tried to remember; the memories were like cold knives in her gut, but combing through them in heaven and in the presence of her god helped make that easier to do. Suddenly, she blinked. Thought harder, trying to confirm the fleeting fragment of a memory. Her wide, bewildered gaze turned back to Anubis. ‚Äú‚Ä¶ Ludin didn‚Äôt kill me, did he? The‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs someone else, someone‚Ä¶ did something to him, I‚Ä¶ saw‚Ä¶ And they‚Äôre still‚Ä¶ out there, aren‚Äôt they?‚Äù Anubis‚Äô gaze lidded slightly, and He gave a soft sigh. Yes. The word was heavy and solemn. They believe they have succeeded in their goal. For now, you are safe. His gaze slid to Kaleva, and a subtle shimmer transitioned the color of His eyes to that borealis teal as they fixed on the tiefling. Take respite in the eye of the storm. But those who hungered are not yet sated.
Dakota 8/8/2023 4:48 PM
Kaleva met Anubis' gaze, understanding reflected in his exhausted, heartsick features. He'd brought this on Skena. Not directly, not willingly, but they would not have targeted Skena if not for him and who she was to him. And even though he knew better than to fault himself for this, that seed of guilt and regret nestled in there regardless. He felt like he'd failed Anubis in keeping Skena safe. Failed Him in bringing this danger to Skena in the first place. Failed Skena, too. As Anubis said, they were in the eye of the storm. It wasn't over yet. She was still in danger. He couldn't fail them again. In the living room, while the two of them communed with their God, Arsast had taken a cookie from the tin and snuck it into Skena's hand. She had to be hungry. If her body was a new thing, there was nothing in her system at all, and who didn't feel better after a talk with Dad and something sweet to eat? He then went to sit next to Ingrid, cloven hooves kicking back and forth. Jaska, however... When Skena had re-emerged, hadn't even looked at him when she spoke to Axa... Logically, he knew she wasn't to blame, not with what she'd experienced. But emotions didn't work on logic, and the hurt and feeling of rejection had taken root in his heart regardless. It didn't show outwardly other than in stony silence. Not until Skena was deep in her communion with Anubis, and he gathered Axa up and stood, heading outside to walk the perimeter, ignoring Luka's confused and hesitant, "...Jaska?"
Daarka 8/8/2023 5:00 PM
As the two communed, the rest gathered in their home would notice subtle, but noteworthy changes to them both. There was a golden shimmer to the air around them, like a dreamy, divine little sandstorm encircling them timelessly. Skena's halo glittered along with it in full force, motes of golden light like stardust swirling around her crown, and even further strengthened by the subtle appearance of a backlit glow around her head. But Kaleva, too, seemed touched by the magic. Similarly subtle ripples of light--shifting ethereally between rich greens and blues--trailed from the tips of his horns, like little echoes of the northern lights that wisped away into the sandstorm of magic around them. It very nearly looked like a halo of his own. Anubis watched Kaleva's face with understanding. He was quiet a moment, before speaking again, His words gentler. The kindness you have shown to those most starved of such gestures is not failure. It is easy to guard oneself, and be braced for turmoil at every turn. It is a greater feat of strength to extend trust and compassion. His other hand reached to gently cup the side of Kaleva's cheek, as He had with Skena. I am proud of the choices you have made. The victory of your enemies would be the death of that spirit in you. (edited)
Dakota 8/8/2023 5:09 PM
Kaleva made a wet little sniffle when Anubis cupped his cheek, tucking his face into His palm, soaking in the comfort and support. His throat was still closed up in a way that made it hard to speak, but he knew that didn't matter here, that Anubis would know him regardless. He didn't know what it would take to put an end to Fenrir and his cult, but he'd do what he had to, so that he and Skena could live the way Anubis had predicted they would. They weren't alone, and that made the task ahead seem more manageable and less terrifying than it would be otherwise.
Daarka 8/8/2023 6:24 PM
Anubis leaned forward again, gently tucking His muzzle between their heads. Skena curled into Him, her hand not tangled in Kaleva's lifting to grasp at the short fur on the side of the god's neck, burying her face into it. Breathing deep of that unearthly scent that filled her with something almost like nostalgia, a feeling of ancient peace, like a lullaby. A part of her wanted to try to find its likeness in the mortal world. The rest of her knew the whole nature of it was that such a thing would be impossible. The warm breeze swirled around them both again, stirring their hair. And then, suddenly, they were back in their home, sitting in front of the shrine, the scent of incense wafting from the little trail of smoke that had been lit. The shimmer in the air gently faded away, but the halos lingered. Both of them. The hand that had been pressed into Anubis' fur now held... a cookie. Skena blinked down at it a few times, trying to reorient herself, before drawing in a deep, steadying breath. She was okay. She was well and truly safe. No illusion of hell could replicate the voice of her father, she was sure of that. Which meant... She looked up, finally looking across the faces of those gathered. Their home had never been so full. Her vision quickly blurred with hot tears, now that she was able to actually accept that sight for what it was--and a second passed, before she caught the glimmers of green and blue in her blurry periphery. She blinked rapidly a few times, focusing on the sleepily rippling lights trailing in an ethereal arc behind the tips of Kaleva's horns, at times shifting together as if to form the shape of his horns into a loop. Her gaze softened deeply, marveling at the little spectacle a moment. "... Go look in the mirror, Kaleva," she breathed quietly.
Dakota 8/8/2023 8:11 PM
Kaleva blinked back at her, distracted from admiring her own halo and reaching up to lightly glide his fingers along those little golden lights as they came back out of the vision. His brow twitched into a slight furrow, and he stood from where they'd sat in front of the shrine, slowly releasing her hand to step into the bathroom to take a peek in the mirror. The sight of his own little aurora borealis halo had him blinking several times, completely baffled and awed, reaching up to pass his fingers through the lights as though they might have physical form. Achoris hovered near them with a lopside smirk, arms folded across his chest. "Welcome to the aasimar club, I guess?" "Important question," Arsast chimed in. "Would we call him a tiefimar, or an assling?"
Daarka 8/8/2023 8:21 PM
The light swirled around Kaleva's fingers--much like how Skena's own behaved, giving no tactile collision to his touch, but moving as if affected by the motions of his fingers anyways, like running his hand through drops of ink in water. Skena's gaze tore away from staring at her best friend's newest evolution, as Arsast and Achoris' voices reminded her of those present. She looked around the faces of everyone gathered, once again moved to the point of getting choked up... before she quickly realized there was someone missing who had been glimpsed a moment earlier. "... Where's Jaska...?" She said slowly, glancing towards his siblings. Valentine gave her a small, sympathetic smile. "He got up to walk around a moment ago. I'm not sure where he ended up." A beat. "... He has had a particularly hard day. I'm sure he would appreciate a hug," she suggested gently, her words soft and quiet, as if Jaska was standing just outside eavesdropping. Skena didn't need any more coaxing. With another brief glance towards Kaleva--and the subtle presence of divinity on him giving her ample reassurance that, for at least a moment, she could part from his side without inviting further trauma--she ran across the room, pushing out the door and jogging out into the grass (still barefoot), looking around to find Jaska.
8:22 PM
Back inside, Ingrid cocked her head thoughtfully. "Assling is certainly a banger."
Dakota 8/8/2023 8:36 PM
Kaleva let out a muffled snort, not quite a laugh but near enough, watching the shimmering colors slowly drifting around his head and his horns, just like they did in the lands of his birth. Outside of his dreams of Anubis, it had been... far too many years since he'd seen them. But he knew them, the shifting electric green and teal, with whispers of purple and pink. Outside, Jaska was walking around the perimeter of the cabin, Axa in his arms, his body language somewhat stiff and compressed, his tail held low and close to his legs. He glanced over at her at the sound of her bare feet in the grass, and just as quickly looked away again, idly running his fingers through Axa's hair. As she approached, he spoke, his tone even and distant. "Have you thought of what you wanted to do with your former body? I understand Kaleva prepared it for burial, and had Cassiana preserve it from decomposing."
Daarka 8/8/2023 8:37 PM
Skena didn't stop running. She ran all the way into him, throwing her arms around him--Axa in his arms and all--and buried her face into his side.
Dakota 8/8/2023 8:49 PM
Jaska froze at the sudden contact, every muscle contracted into rigid lines, his eyes widening slightly and his lips pressed tight together. He glanced at her sharply, then away, taking every scrap of composure he had to not crumble. He stood frozen for several long moments, then gradually shifted to lower Axa down to the ground. "Go stay with Valentine for a moment," he murmured to Axa. "I'll be right in."
Daarka 8/8/2023 8:52 PM
Axa lingered a second as she was placed back on the ground, watching him a little uncertainly. But she had never disobeyed a direct request from him, and she wouldn't be starting today. A little reluctantly, she padded back across the grass, soon disappearing around the corner. Skena had released him enough to allow him to set Axa down, but hadn't really stepped back, still very much within his personal bubble. As the little girl disappeared, she looked up at the tiefling, pain and empathy and a tangle of other emotions stitched across her face. "... I'm so sorry, Jaska," she whispered quietly.
Dakota 8/8/2023 8:58 PM
"For what?" he asked, shortly and a little sharply, his arms folding across his chest in a subtly insecure and defensive display. He still could barely look at her. It made his eyes sting.
Daarka 8/8/2023 9:08 PM
"For the... the day you've had. All of it. And..." her jaw clenched a little. "... That was... That was so rude of me, wasn't it?" She squeaked. "I... I just... I-I knew what that... sword did. And... when I... When I woke up and it didn't look like hell... I... I knew it had to be. The last... I don't even know how long," she admitted with an exhausted exhale (the correct answer was about twenty-four hours), "I haven't... been able to rest, or think, or... I've just... been waiting for the curtain to lift, and for me to actually see I'm in hell. When... When the place I woke up in was... nice and comfortable, it just... I was convinced that was part of the trick. To raise my hopes before they'd be dashed on the ground, so the fall would... hurt more. When I... saw Kaleva's face, I... I wanted... so much to be reassured... but I... I couldn't relax. All of your faces, I... I couldn't relax. I felt like... as soon as I allowed myself to be comforted, it would just... all go away, and..." She swallowed, looking up. Actually meeting his gaze now. "... I'm... I'm sorry. I-I didn't mean to be rude. I... I needed... I needed to know it was real, or I'd... the panic would never go away. If... If I ran to hug you, and... and you... weren't you, I... I don't think I could ever recover from that. I... needed you to be you. And you are. I-I know that now. And I'm... I'm sorry. I'm sorry you... had to experience any of this. I-I don't know what your time has been like, but I'm... I'm so sorry, Jaska."
Dakota 8/8/2023 9:26 PM
"Skena, stop." He held up a hand, and finally managed to glance down at her, his tail curled tight and low around his legs. "You died. The circumstances of what happened after your death could not have been foreseen. The way you reacted is perfectly logical and reasonable given the information you were working with, and I am perfectly aware of that." A pause. "Also, you don't get to apologize for dying, that's stupid." To most people, he would have probably seemed cold and uncaring. But Skena wasn't most people, and she knew him to a degree only his siblings could share. It was taking literally everything he had not to break down. He had experienced many emotions of extreme intensities, but none of them had been loss, and he didn't know how to process it. He was hanging onto his composure by the skin of his teeth.
Daarka 8/8/2023 9:28 PM
Skena's gaze softened as he spoke, clear compassion and concern for him--and a fair bit of shared pain--on her face. The hand he held up to stop her, she reached to take in her own. "... You wanna go sit down by the smoke shed and cry?" She offered quietly, the suggestion innocent and earnest and full to the brim with understanding. After all, she had just cried her guts out, violently, for about an hour. "I won't tell anyone."
Dakota 8/8/2023 9:37 PM
He frowned as she took his hand. Like she had taken every defense he'd thrown up and just went 'nah' and squeezed on in regardless. And he resented her for it as much as he loved her for it. "...That sounds vile. And uncomfortable. And undignified. No. You might be able to get away with such a gross display of emotion, but I'm fairly certain I would spontaneously combust."
Daarka 8/8/2023 9:44 PM
"It is uncomfortable," she admitted. "But when it's over, you feel a hundred pounds lighter." She continued to hold his hand, watching him patiently and with... a soft affection. "... You sound uncomfortable right now, anyways." A beat. "... I'm sure everyone in there has... just... been having a uniquely rough time." But he was the one she ran to see--though she did not put that to words. "I... I know I don't need to... apologize for dying, but... I... I'm still sorry I left you," she added, quieter. "Really sorry. Sorry like I should have been... safer or something, though I know theres a good amount of that I don't deserve to burden myself with. But also sorry just... in the sympathetic sense. Even if I am wholly without blame, I'm... I'm sorry for what you've gone through. It's heartbreaking to think about it. And... I'm sure I haven't done my last crying about it all. You... You didn't do anything wrong, either. You didn't deserve to get hurt."
Dakota 8/8/2023 9:51 PM
"Yeah, well, that never stopped me before," he muttered, turning to walk over toward the smoke shed, his hand still held in hers. Not actively curling around her hand in return, but not trying to pull it away either. "Your other body is in your workshop. I can have it removed if you don't want to see it."
Daarka 8/8/2023 9:55 PM
She easily followed him, making no comment on his apparent acceptance of her offer. She was silent a few moments after his comment, her face twisting slightly. "... I... I don't really... know what I want. With that." A pause. "I'll... I'll deal with that later, I think. There... I don't know. It's--It's not every day you find yourself with two bodies. There might be some use I could glean from it..." Her free hand tiredly rubbed at her puffy eyes. "Maybe I can... do my own autopsy. Make sure I didn't have some sort of tumor worth worrying about. I always wondered what else might be weird about my guts, since my blood is so unusual," she added, a bit wryly. The words sounded tired, like there was a fifty-fifty chance she was serious.
Dakota 8/8/2023 10:02 PM
He let out a snort, bringing her around to the side where they were out of sight of the windows in the cabin and going to sit down with his back to the side of the wood and stone building, the smoky scent of woodfire and cooked meat saturated into it. "Kaleva would be the one to ask, if you didn't want to do it yourself. He prepared you Cautican-style. Organs in jars. What is the point of that?"
Daarka 8/8/2023 10:13 PM
Her eyes widened slightly at that news, as she settled down next to him, her side pressed against his. For a moment, she was too moved by the knowledge that Kaleva, even in the depths of his grief, had tried to lay her to rest as she would have wanted. Just as she was simultaneously torn apart that he had to endure such an experience at all. "... Every religion believes something different about what happens to you when you die," she finally responded, her words hushed as those emotions washed over her. "I don't think I was actually dead long enough to find out what the correct answer is, either. But... in Cautica, and with the teachings I was raised with... Anubis is a funerary god. One of His most well-known impacts in our culture was the introduction of our burial practices. Of mummification. We... believe that when we die, the condition of our worldly bodies is, more or less, what we have to work with in the afterlife, as well. So it is customary for remains to be preserved, so that the deceased steps beyond the veil with dignity and strength as much as possible. Organs are hard to preserve... there's so much moisture in them, they rot very quickly. So they are removed, and the tissues that remain are treated to dehydrate them." A beat. "The hearts remain, though, because the deceased will need theirs in the afterlife. The heart is what Anubis will weigh upon His scales to see how you lived your life, and consequentially, how you proceed in the afterlife." As she spoke, her fingers of the hand opposite the one holding Jaska's lifted, a subconscious movement that ended in her fingertips ghosting over the front of her sternum. Her heart must have been so heavily damaged. An insult added to the injury she could only imagine Kaleva enduring, inevitable for him to take notice of if he was emptying her body of viscera. "... It's because I had that upbringing," she continued after a long, distracted moment, "that I was able to craft Gummy. He's preserved and maintained through much of those same methods and teachings."
Dakota 8/9/2023 9:35 PM
Jaska drew one leg up and let their joined hands rest on his upturned knee, sucking on his teeth as he stared off into the woods. "...I suppose there are stranger funerary practices." It occurred to him that he might be being selfish, sequestering Skena out here like this. Plenty of people had mourned her death, had been distressed by it. But Kaleva got first dibs, and he had zero qualms about shoving Achoris out of the way to claim some attention. He leaned slightly further into the shared line of contact at their sides.
Daarka 8/9/2023 9:40 PM
Skena comfortably nestled up against him as well, not nearly as reserved as he was as she went so far as to rest her cheek on his shoulder. She was quiet for a while. "... Do you think Axa even cared?" She wondered after a moment, not sounding particularly affected at the idea that the girl might not have. "I can never tell if she actually likes me or not."
Dakota 8/9/2023 9:51 PM
"I think she was distressed because I was distressed," he murmured. "You are important to me, and therefore, something happening to you being upsetting to me is something that upsets her in turn. We had her try to summon the lemure we thought you had turned into... Had prepared a receptacle to contain you until we could find a means to return you to your body. It didn't work, and that distressed her greatly, but... I believe that was because it should have worked. Would have, if you had actually been a lemure. But we hadn't realized that wasn't the case, and she was very disturbed about having her expectations fall short."
Daarka 8/9/2023 10:01 PM
Skena was further... humbled. And sobered, as she listened to more details of what had transpired in her absence. It was one thing to know people had thought her dead and all of the presumed emotions that would follow that had been endured. It was another to... hear of the ways they had chosen to handle those events. The things done to her body. The efforts taken to recover her somehow. Even if she was a lemure. Even if she was a lemure. "... I can imagine... how that failing when it shouldn't have would upset her," she agreed softly after a moment. A beat. "... I wasn't thinking clearly. I've... I've been in a blind panic this entire time," she added, her words a faint whisper. "All of my belongings were here, of course. I couldn't use my magic. I couldn't... reach out. I couldn't tell anyone where I thought I was or what was going on. I'm... I'm not even sure if the magic would have worked, even if I had my amulet, knowing now that I wasn't on the same plane as the rest of you. Some things don't carry over in extraplanar ways like that." She paused, before relenting, "... And that would have just... made the panic worse, I guess. If I tried, and it failed. The... The letter said I was in a demiplane, but... I didn't know how much of what was written I should believe. I thought if I wasn't in hell... then I was going to end up back in Cautica." She swallowed, drawing in a deep breath. "... I wish there had been something I could have done to give you all some sort of... peace of mind. Assurance." Even as she said it... she wasn't sure that she would have had the guts to try, even if such a thing was made available to her. Because trying meant the chance that it would fail, and that failure would have dashed her sanity across the sandstone floors. (edited)
